**Fascicle Five**
**Supreme Primordial Chapter on the Six Harmonies’ Life Tallies**

**Chapter on Petitioning the Three Heavens for Lifespan**

*Compiled by Master Guangcheng, Du Guangting, of the Supreme Proclamation of Compassion and Transformative Aid*

**Chapter on Emergency Relief and Crisis Resolution**
For those afflicted by yearly calamities, monthly misfortunes, the exhaustion of fate’s tally, the severance of life’s allotted blessings, or the encroachment of one’s active year’s malign influences, this oral petition for emergency relief should be presented. Thereby, disasters shall be dispelled, and fortune and prosperity shall descend at once.

By day, face east; by night, face north.
Prepare a pair of silver ingots, one hundred twenty tally sticks, twelve feet of azure silk thread, one thousand two hundred cash as sincerity money, one *shi* and two *dou* of life rice, and two *zhang* and four *chi* of life silk.

Proceed to ignite the incense burner,
then kneel and declare your office:

To the Supreme Mystery Capital of the Orthodox Unity, the Balanced Qi, and the Celestial Master’s twenty-four dioceses of Yangping and the like, your subject [Name] bows his head and prostrates himself, offering this reverent address:

According to the records, your subject, a disciple of [such-and-such] Abbey in [such-and-such] Prefecture, [such-and-such] County, [such-and-such] Township, and [such-and-such] Village, aged [so many] years, with [so many] household members residing herein, today kowtows to beseech blessings and implore grace. This mortal, born of flesh and blood, descendant of the hundred officials, has through a thousand ages of fortune been privileged to serve the Supreme Great Dao and the Lords and Venerable Ones. Entrusted with the imperial mandate, he governs his own life and household. Yet this mortal, [Name], along with his entire household, great and small, has been foolish and obstinate, acting in frequent contravention of the Dao. Thus, misfortune has accrued, and in recent years, adversity has prevailed, leaving his household in decline and distress. Wealth and property have dissipated, malevolent spirits have arisen in competition, and he fears that the three disasters and nine calamities have converged upon his person. Ensnared by the celestial net and enmeshed in the earthly web, his lifespan is foreshortened, his years nearly spent. He petitions the Three Officials to absolve his name from death’s register. Moreover, the earth of his ancestral tombs has been severed, causing the restless dead to stir and bring misfortune. The consequences recur in what he witnesses: litigation ensnares the living. In this turbid and wicked age, a hundred evils rage violently, demonic bandits roam freely, and a hundred maladies bring slaughter. The deaths of ordinary folk lie strewn like refuse, their wails filling the roads, unbearable to hear. This mortal, dwelling amidst such peril, finds no merit by which to extricate himself. He deeply fears that he will suddenly be reduced to dust, unable to preserve his own existence, and without recourse. Thus, with a single heart, he surrenders his fate to the Great Dao, entreating your subject to present this petition and memorial, to dissolve the three disasters and nine calamities that afflict his life, to unbind the snares that entangle him, and to redeem his life from its destined end.

As enumerated in his plea, your subject, in his foolishness, remains ignorant of the workings of demonic *qi*. He fears that his person may be assailed by the six harms, that mutual afflictions may arise, or that malevolent apparitions may invade and wrong him. He also fears that he may be pursued by the *qi* of ancestral tombs—by the dead of his lineage, both inner and outer, and by demonic bandits—summoned arbitrarily by the Lord of Mount Tai. Though this mortal is indeed sinful and defiled, like the lowly sparrow or mouse, he turns to the Dao to seek mercy.

It is heard that the Supreme Great Dao, in its compassion, nurtures all beings, leaving none unsaved. To extend life and avert calamity, one need only beseech its boundless grace. Thus, he presents this oral petition in the central courtyard, beneath the Great Yin and before the Northern Dipper, prostrating himself to submit this memorial, that it may ascend to the Celestial Bureau.

He humbly prays that the Boundless Supreme Lord Lao, the Supreme Venerable Ones, the Three Master Lords, the Compassionate Father, and the Holy Mother may bestow their boundless grace, absolving the myriad mortal sins and transgressions this mortal has committed since birth, along with the nine calamities’ appointed hour. May all be swept away. May this mortal be granted one life, one survival, one passage, one deliverance. If his three destinies are exhausted and his tally’s reckoning spent, may he be specially granted length in the midst of shortness, success in the midst of failure, safety in the midst of peril, and deliverance in the midst of calamity. May the fleeting moments be reversed, and a single term of life be lent.

He petitions the deities of his life’s natal month to each lead a thousand chariots and ten thousand riders, to rescue and resolve the calamities that threaten his life. Thereupon, he presents this written plea to beg for the tally of the *zi* and *wu* hours, extending his years to one hundred twenty. He beseeches that his name be substituted, his form transformed, his evil ledgers erased, and his shortness exchanged for length. May his fate be transmuted and extended, his years prolonged to their utmost, and may he be advanced beneath the guidance of the stellar net, where mutual redemption may be achieved.

If this mortal’s life is frail and weak, may it be extended; if his granaries are depleted, may their measures be increased; if his trees wither, may they be revived by nourishing rains. If his three lifespans are foreshortened, may they be prolonged; if his years and fate are brief, may his tally and blessings be augmented.

He respectfully summons the divine soldiers, the lictors, and the messengers to bear the ledgers of his life’s tally and records, presenting them before the Jade Emperor. There, in accordance with the matter at hand, they shall be reviewed by the Gatekeeper of Life’s Mandate. May the charges be assessed, the records examined, and the petitions granted to halt execution and stay the sentence.

If this mortal’s life is truly limited, its span too brief, the nine calamities converging, his conduct often wayward, his viscera filled with sin, and his sentence justly decreed; if his three destinies are nearly spent, the three absolutions already reported; if his name is absent from the Jade Calendar, his left tally unrecorded, his entry missing from the Three Primordials’ register, his name stricken from the Life Mandate’s ledgers, unclaimed by the Southern Palace, and unforgiven by the Heavenly Emperor—then he begs that these be expunged. Once every three months, once every three years, may the grand assembly recur in endless cycle. Should his plea be heeded, he shall receive the grace of his masters and elders, reborn through their favor.

He petitions the Lord of Lifespan in the Hall of Literary Glory, along with the Lords of Augmented Tally and Life’s Deliverance, five each, accompanied by twelve hundred officials and generals, to descend as one and preside over the extension of his life, the augmentation of his lifespan, and the eternal preservation of his existence.

He further petitions the Lords of Stellar Tally Adjustment, Name Transformation, and Death’s Transcendence from the Supreme Primordial Mysterious Black Palace, five each, accompanied by twelve hundred officials and generals, to descend as one. Together with the lictors and messengers within his person, and the reviewing officers beneath the Great Yin, they shall act on behalf of this mortal, ascending to the Palace of the Northern Dipper’s Handmaidens to redeem his name from death’s register and transform his form.

He petitions the Nine Dragon Talismanic Mandate from the Eastern Florescence Palace to be issued to the Immortal Lords of the Five Marchmounts, commanding the Water Official, the River Earl, Lord Lü, and the twenty-four wardens of Mount Tai’s prisons.

chunks.original_text: 三台，八座司命，解除某身中罪，考一切和释，为拔出三魂七魄付与身中，不得放逸，请拘魂制魄君五人，官将千二百人，又请东方七童子，拔魂魄吏万二千人，为径诣玄阴御女宫中，主为拔赎某三魂七魄，拔出三命，永保生活，又请南昌主真君五人，官将千二百人，一合来下，随臣章上诣 太浩天曹司命韩君门下玉案上，主为某却三官死解，更定生名，度着左契玉历神仙簿中，延年无穷，又请魁纲君五人，官将百二十人，主为某身上解生月胞胎，生日所犯五星二十八宿，下解孤虚灭没之厄，五灾九厄之炁，赐纯阳生炁布润某身。 所苦千灾万痛，应章除差，恐立命以来犯触天地四时。 五行十二时辰，二十四神，天纲河魁，太一从魁功曹，传送大吉小吉，胜先神后太冲，征明青龙白虎，朱雀玄武，螣蛇天后，太阴天一，贵神日游月行，千禁万忌，殃考深重，应充鬼伴者，愿七星君，次为消除之，贪狼巨门，除断鬼源，禄存廉贞，代名易形，文曲武曲，除却死录，天纲破军，斤却妖群，使不加人，三台主除墓，考千罪万过，十二刑杀之鬼，一切消灭，所患除愈，愿上官典者，为通行省理，令章上诣 三天曹，分别某家昔世已来，九玄七祖，父母及某身积行所犯顽逆丑恶，非人所行，淫色盗窃、违天负地，形梼咒诅、复连之炁，并肉人某身行年本命诸灾厄衰祸之炁，次解除五刑六害，短寿之厄，延年益等，六甲六十日旬，阴阳六十神，各自驱使，捡统四海八极，十四州九十郡，一千二百县、万二千乡亭、万二千里域之中，推某身所犯，并是何罪何事，在何宫在何司，何府何神所喷，为何鬼所言，为何考所逮，乞所召君将吏兵，上诣 三天曹道行之处，次为和释消灭之，使天无文书、地无简籍、水无盟誓，一切为原之。 重请仓火玉女千二百人，各衣珠玉杂色之衣，三环结角，主为某延年益寿，添仓益库，更加寿等，起百二十神炁，流布某身中，上升泥丸，下治绛宫，养育根元，补护年命，乞医理疾，病豁然除差，登行道路，又请玄老大将军十万人，玄老使者百万众，又请三天太上玉女千二百人，三环结角身着五色玄黄衣，足着师子履，三天上来下，口含雄黄之药，手捧玉浆，吐哺真炁，共来济疗肉人，某身从头至足，绿肌缠脉，和调六腑，筋骨充满，百病除差，梦寤真正，得度九厄之中，主为某身中上解除天厄。 下解除地厄，次解三天星辰之厄，次解胎月之厄，吹解生日之厄，次解年衰算尽之厄，次解嫁娶移徙葬埋犯触十二时神之厄，次解大将军太岁太阴十二月建王之厄，次解行年绝气之厄，次解违天负地之厄，次解元辰衰否之厄，又恐某身本命众厄兼会，有五方，驱除夷蛮戎狄及中外强畔，四面咒诅，克害，致令肉人疾病厄困万痛加某身，命在时克恐不兔三灾九厄之中，雀鼠之命，畏死贪生，重请三天解厄君五人，官将千二百人，又请太皇万福君五人，官将千二百人，主为某身於九天之下、九地之上，检寻某算籍，主知祸祟根元，灾厄深浅，一切悉为和合，次消灭之解而度之，乞丐肉人某身百病去体，十善来亲，千灾消灭，万福唯新，重请南昌君五人，官将百二十人，摄录肉人身中三尸九虫，无令越逸，伺人罪过，佐助未周，牵引外邪，阴改贼病，一时消灭，愿上官与者随事料理，所请天官，以时差遣君将吏兵，各摄所部，尽除恶害，收捕邪炁，解除和释，众精魍魉，奇鬼妖魅，托形诸杂，神鬼盘固不去者，请天中敢健吏兵士千二百人，一合来下，到肉人居宅里中，收捕精祟万邪为害，令内外清洁，神明防卫，特乞某身康体健，真炁降流补润四支，宁安五藏，调理百关，厄中得度，死中得生，彻灭短籍，着名长生玉历之中，千罪万过一切赦除，蒙恩之日，臣谨仰宣妙法，劝喻肉人，修善改恶，伏从科戒，不使复犯天官，营护有劳，随臣都章，言功举迁，以为效信，恩惟

The Three Terraces and the Eight Seats of the Controller of Destiny shall absolve the transgressions within this petitioner’s person, reviewing and releasing all karmic bonds. They shall retrieve his three hun and seven po souls and restore them to his body, ensuring they do not wander astray. He petitions five Lords of the Restrained Hun and Controlled Po, accompanied by twelve hundred officials and generals, and further petitions the Seven Lads of the East, along with twelve thousand clerks of the retrieved hun and po, to proceed directly to the Palace of the Mysterious Yin Handmaidens. There, they shall revoke his death decrees from the Three Offices, redefine his life’s name, and inscribe him in the Jade Register of Divine Immortals on the Left Covenant, granting him boundless years.

He further petitions five Lords of the Stellar Net, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to dissolve the lunar womb and placenta of his birth, absolving the transgressions of his natal Five Stars and Twenty-Eight Constellations. They shall dispel the calamities of solitary void and annihilation, the qi of the Five Disasters and Nine Perils, and bestow upon him the pure yang qi of generation, suffusing his body.

For the thousand afflictions and myriad pains that plague him, may they be eradicated upon the submission of this memorial. Yet he fears that since the establishment of his destiny, he has unwittingly violated the laws of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, the Five Phases, the twelve double-hours, the Twenty-Four Spirits, the Celestial Net, the River Earl, the Great Unity, the Follower of the Chief Star, the Merit Clerk, the Messenger, the Great Fortune, the Lesser Fortune, the Victorious Advance, the Divine Rear, the Grand Impact, the Punitive Brightness, the Azure Dragon, the White Tiger, the Vermilion Bird, the Dark Warrior, the Coiling Serpent, the Queen of Heaven, the Great Yin, the Celestial Unity, the Noble Spirit, the Daily Patrol, the Monthly Procession, and the thousand prohibitions and myriad taboos—accumulating grave misfortunes that consign him to the company of ghosts. He beseeches the Seven Stars: may Tainlang and Jumen sever the roots of spectral affliction; may Lucun and Lianzhen alter his name and transform his form; may Wenqu and Wuqu expunge his death records; may Tian’gang and Pojun cleave asunder demonic hordes, preventing their harm. May the Three Terraces absolve the sins of his tomb and the thousand transgressions of his past, annihilating the ghosts of the Twelve Punitive Executions. May all his sufferings be cured.

He prays that the overseeing officials will facilitate and govern, allowing his memorial to ascend to the Three Heavenly Courts. There, they shall distinguish the transgressions of his family from past lives—his Nine Ancestral Kin and Seven Generations, his parents, and himself—accumulated through obstinate rebellion, shameful deeds, inhuman conduct, lust, theft, defiance of Heaven and betrayal of Earth, curses and imprecations, and the qi of karmic entanglement. Alongside the calamities of his current year and destiny, they shall dissolve the Five Punishments, the Six Harms, and the perils of short life, extending his years and augmenting his fate. May the Six Jia and the sixty-day cycles, the Yin and Yang of the sixty spirits, each command their legions, inspecting the Four Seas and Eight Extremities, the Fourteen Provinces and Ninety Prefectures, the One Thousand Two Hundred Counties, the Twelve Thousand Townships, and the Twelve Thousand Li of domains. They shall trace the transgressions of his person, identifying the nature of his sins, the offices and bureaus they offend, the deities and spirits they provoke, the ghosts that accuse him, and the inquisitors that seize him. He implores the summoned lords, generals, officials, and soldiers to ascend to the Three Heavenly Courts and the paths of the Dao, there to reconcile and annihilate these transgressions, ensuring that Heaven holds no records, Earth no registers, and Water no oaths—all shall be absolved.

He earnestly petitions one thousand two hundred Jade Maidens of the Granary Fire, each clad in garments of pearls and jade in variegated hues, their hair bound in triple knots. They shall extend his years and augment his life, filling his granaries and treasuries, further enhancing his longevity. They shall summon the qi of one hundred twenty spirits, suffusing his body, ascending to the Muddy Pellet and descending to the Crimson Palace, nurturing his root and origin, fortifying his years and destiny. He beseeches healing for his ailments, that his maladies vanish in an instant, and that his journeys be unimpeded.

He petitions the Great General of the Mysterious Elder, one hundred thousand strong, and the Envoys of the Mysterious Elder, one million in number. He further petitions one thousand two hundred Jade Maidens of the Three Heavens, their hair bound in triple knots, their bodies clad in five-colored garments of mysterious yellow, their feet shod in lion-skin slippers. Descending from the Three Heavens, they shall hold cinnabar in their mouths and bear jade nectar in their hands, exhaling true qi to heal and restore this mortal. From head to foot, they shall harmonize his green muscles and entwined vessels, regulate his six bowels, strengthen his sinews and bones, cure his hundred ailments, and rectify his dreams and waking hours. He shall pass through the Nine Perils, as they absolve the calamities of Heaven above and Earth below, the perils of the Three Heavenly Stars, the womb and lunar months, the afflictions of his birth hour, the exhaustion of his years and fate, the transgressions of marriage, relocation, burial, and the twelve hourly spirits, the calamities of the Grand General, the Grand Yin, the twelve monthly constructions, the exhaustion of his current year’s qi, the defiance of Heaven and betrayal of Earth, and the adversities of his destiny’s decline. Fearing that the confluence of his natal perils may summon the barbarians of the Five Directions—Yi, Man, Rong, and Di—along with internal and external adversaries, the curses from all sides, and the harm that brings illness, distress, and myriad pains to his body, he dreads that his life may not escape the Three Disasters and Nine Perils, that his fate may be as fleeting as a sparrow’s or a mouse’s, and that his fear of death and longing for life compel him to earnestly petition five Lords of the Three Heavens’ Calamity Absolution, with twelve hundred officials and generals, and five Lords of the Myriad Blessings of the Grand August, with twelve hundred officials and generals. They shall inspect his fate’s register beneath the Nine Heavens and above the Nine Earths, discerning the roots of his misfortunes and the depth of his calamities, reconciling and annihilating all.

He implores that his hundred ailments depart his body, that the Ten Virtues draw near, that a thousand disasters vanish, and that myriad fortunes renew. He earnestly petitions five Lords of Southern Prosperity, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to seize and record the Three Corpses and Nine Worms within his body, preventing their escape, their surveillance of his transgressions, their incomplete assistance, their attraction of external malevolence, and their covert sabotage of his health—may all be annihilated at once.

He prays that the overseeing officials will manage each matter accordingly, dispatching the celestial officials and their legions of lords, generals, officials, and soldiers to eradicate all harm, capture malevolent qi, absolve and reconcile, and expel the myriad spirits, specters, and demons—whether they cling in strange forms, as miscellaneous gods and ghosts, or stubbornly linger. He petitions one thousand two hundred valiant soldiers of the Heavenly Center to descend as one to his dwelling, capturing and subduing the ten thousand malevolent spirits that plague him, purifying his inner and outer domains, and fortifying them with divine protection. He beseeches that his body be robust, that true qi descend to nourish and replenish his four limbs, pacify his five viscera, regulate his hundred passages, and deliver him from peril, granting him life amidst death. May his short register be obliterated and his name inscribed in the Jade Record of Longevity. May his thousand sins and myriad transgressions be pardoned in its entirety.

On the day he receives this grace, he shall reverently proclaim the wondrous Dharma, exhorting this mortal to cultivate virtue, amend his faults, and humbly adhere to the precepts and prohibitions, never again offending the celestial officials. In gratitude for their vigilant protection, he shall submit this comprehensive memorial, recounting their merits and advocating for their promotion, as a token of his sincerity. Thus, he petitions with deepest reverence.

chunks.original_text: 具章奏法位姓某谨重封 三天门下请进 南岳魏夫人生算度厄章 泰玄都正一平炁，系天师阳平等二十四治炁三洞道士臣某，稽首顿首，再拜上言，谨案文书，今有某州某县某乡某里某官弟子某，即日叩头乞恩，禳灾解厄救病，断绝外□，复连安神定魄章词，但弟子某千生有幸，得奉 大道太上诸君丈人道法，因玄都香火以自保护，得在清化，诚用忻悦罔极之恩，但由弟子某胎生顽愚，不闲科典，奉道多违，招延考逮，比来轗轲，宅舍不安，鬼毒临守，人神虚耗，钱财支散，田蚕不收，六畜损伤，人口疾患，灾厄相仍，常常梦寐，与先亡混杂，卜决云是太祖父母、伯叔兄弟、姑姨舅氏姊妹诸房，腥臭死鬼，遽相牵引，共来为祟，致令弟子某身及家口大小，卜梦凶丑，所见非真，且见今时鬼贼流行，枉暴良善，遭罹病珍，死亡者众，弟子某家口大小，处在其间，虑不免脱，惊惶恐怖，告请无方，唯以一心，上凭 大道，求生乞活，告诉向臣请乞章奏，以自禳解，小臣下愚，不明科法，依案天师千二百口章，考问精祟所由，弟子某口辞，自列卜决，唯言有先亡后死、太祖父母、伯叔兄弟姊妹、姑姨舅氏诸亲外□等鬼，各以往岁疾病死亡，或值日恶时凶、今来为祟，克病生人，弟子某身及家口大小，灾厄困苦如此，或生名不定，或名入死解之中，今为追解，上计生算，延年度厄，救急治病，乞得除却死籍，定上生名。 生属年名本命生月於此云但弟子某家口大小等，所有连星算尽，上计衰厄，乞为延度，某身等或以子岁上计，丑岁上计，寅岁上计，卯岁上计，辰岁上计，巳岁上计，午岁上计，未岁上计，申岁上计，酉岁上计，戌岁上计，亥岁上计，乞为解除之，定上生名，簿籍玉历之中，魂魄归附，灾厄度脱，疾病除差，家口大小，乞得平安，无他，又恐弟子某家口大小等，或以正月上计，二月上计，三月上计，四月上计，五月上计，六月上计，七月上计，八月上计，九月上计，十月上计，十一月上计，十二月上计者，并乞次第为解除之，所有灾厄疾病之者，立蒙度脱，除差了了，人口平安，免灾度难，若弟子等或以子日上计，丑日上计，寅日上计，卯日上计，辰日上计，巳日上计，午日上计，未日上计，申日上计，酉日上计，戌日上计，亥日上计之者，乞真炁兵士，主为弟子等，以次解除之，定上生录，保护家口，乞得疾病除愈，衰厄度脱，鬼炁消灭，人口大小，平安无他，又恐弟子某身及家口大小等身，或以建日上计，除日上计，满日上计，平日上计，定日上计，执日上计，破日上计，危日上计，成日上计，收日上计，开日上计，闭日上计之者，并乞真炁君将吏兵，次为解除削落死籍，定上生名，灾厄度脱，复连断绝，疾病除差，人口平安，又恐弟子某身及家口大小，或以正月上计，死忌在寅，二月上计，死忌在卯，三月上计，死忌在辰，四月上计，死忌在巳，五月上计，死忌在午，六月上计，死忌在未，七月上计，死忌在申，八月上计，死忌在酉，九月上计，死忌在戌，十月上计，死忌在亥，十一月上计，死忌在子，十二月上计，死忌在丑，如上等忌疾厄深重，乞丐 大道真炁官将吏兵，次为弟子垂慈，解除死籍，定上生名，或恐弟子某身及家口大小等，为太岁所临月厄，所守三魂七魄，闭在太山北狱之中，或有太阴大使风伯雨师，自称太岁太阴太阳大将军，北时司命，十二月建，自称官号，时游天下，地上步从，鬼兵歌乐，群行相随，吹角打鼓，把旗执节，自称符庙社稷，自称宅中灶君夫人，自称土公宅龙，自称兵猎逢契李遨之鬼，交通千鬼万神，天下地上百二十种刑厄，恐来害弟子某家，致令遭染病患，精炁离身，魂魄不附，灾厄相守，所向乖违，官横肆起，如此困苦，切急忧惶，恐不免脱，告请元元，情在可愍，臣不胜所见，谨冒罪伏地，拜奏救急解计治病口章一通，上诣

**[Memorial Content]**

Minister [Name], in proper ceremonial rank, respectfully seals this memorial anew.

To the Gate of the Three Heavens, with request for transmission:
**Memorial for Extending Lifespan and Dispelling Calamity by the Lady Wei of the Southern Peak**

By the Orthodox Unity of the Great Mystery, the Balanced Qi of the Supreme Mystery Metropolis, and the lineage of the Celestial Master’s twenty-four dioceses of Yangping and others, your Daoist servant [Name], bows his head and knocks his forehead to the ground, prostrating twice, and respectfully submits:

According to the documents at hand, there is now a certain official disciple [Name] of [Rank], from [Village], [Precinct], [County], [Prefecture], who today kowtows and beseeches grace, seeking to avert disaster, resolve calamity, cure illness, sever external [obstructions], and restore the continuity of the memorial for pacifying spirits and stabilizing the hun and po souls.

This disciple [Name] has been fortunate across a thousand lives to serve the Dao of the Most High and the Lords and Elders of the Great Way. Through the incense fire of the Mystery Metropolis, he has protected himself and dwelt in purity and transformation. Truly, he is filled with boundless gratitude and joy for this grace. Yet, owing to his innate foolishness from birth, he is unversed in the statutes and canons, and in his practice of the Dao has often transgressed, thereby incurring trials and punishments. Of late, his fortunes have been adverse: his dwelling is unsettled, demonic toxins besiege it, spirits and humans are depleted, wealth is squandered, fields and silkworms yield no harvest, livestock perish, and his household suffers illness. Calamities follow one upon another, and in his dreams, he is constantly mingled with the long-deceased. Divination reveals that these are the putrid, foul ghosts of his great-grandparents, uncles, brothers, aunts, maternal uncles, sisters, and other kin, who, having died in illness or on inauspicious days, now return as malevolent spirits, afflicting the living with sickness.

This disciple [Name], along with his entire household, young and old, has encountered ominous and grotesque visions in divination and dreams, seeing what is not real. Moreover, in this present time, demonic brigands run rampant, unjustly harming the good and upright. Many have fallen ill and perished, and this disciple’s household, caught amidst this, fears it cannot escape. Terrified and desperate, with no recourse, he turns with all his heart to the Great Dao, seeking life and sustenance. He petitions your servant to submit this memorial on his behalf for exorcism and deliverance.

This humble servant, dull and ignorant of the statutes and methods, has followed the precedent of the Celestial Master’s "Memorial of the Twelve Hundred Mouths." Upon investigating the origins of the malevolent spirits, the disciple [Name] stated in his own words, as revealed by divination, that these are the ghosts of his deceased ancestors—great-grandparents, uncles, brothers, sisters, aunts, maternal uncles, and other kin—who died of illness in past years or on inauspicious days and now return as malevolent spirits, inflicting sickness upon the living. This disciple [Name] and his entire household, young and old, suffer such afflictions and hardships that some have not had their names fixed in the registers of life, or their names have entered the records of death. Now, he seeks to retroactively resolve this, to tally his lifespan anew, extend his years and avert calamity, cure his illnesses, and beseech the removal of his name from the ledgers of death and its inscription in the registers of life.

[Here follows the disciple’s birth year, name, and natal month.]

This disciple [Name] and his entire household, young and old, have exhausted their allotted stars and lifespans. He beseeches that their declining years and calamities be extended. Whether their tally is reckoned in the year of the Rat, Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, Horse, Goat, Monkey, Rooster, Dog, or Pig, he begs for their resolution, that their names be inscribed in the registers of life, their souls and spirits be restored, calamities be dispelled, illnesses be cured, and his entire household, young and old, be granted peace and safety, free from further harm.

Moreover, he fears that this disciple [Name] and his household may have their tally reckoned in the first, second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth, tenth, eleventh, or twelfth month. He beseeches that these be resolved in order, that all afflictions, calamities, and illnesses be immediately dispelled, his household be at peace, and disasters be averted.

If this disciple and his household have their tally reckoned on the day of the Rat, Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, Horse, Goat, Monkey, Rooster, Dog, or Pig, he begs that the soldiers of the True Qi be dispatched to resolve these in sequence, inscribe their names in the registers of life, protect his household, cure their illnesses, dispel their calamities, eradicate demonic qi, and ensure the safety of his entire household, young and old, free from further harm.

Furthermore, he fears that this disciple [Name] and his household may have their tally reckoned on the Establishing, Removing, Filling, Leveling, Fixing, Holding, Breaking, Perilous, Completing, Gathering, Opening, or Closing days. He beseeches that the generals, officials, and soldiers of the True Qi resolve these in order, expunge their names from the registers of death, inscribe them in the registers of life, dispel calamities, sever obstructions, cure illnesses, and ensure the peace of his household.

He also fears that this disciple [Name] and his household may have their tally reckoned in the first month, with the death taboo in the Tiger; the second month, with the death taboo in the Rabbit; the third month, with the death taboo in the Dragon; the fourth month, with the death taboo in the Snake; the fifth month, with the death taboo in the Horse; the sixth month, with the death taboo in the Goat; the seventh month, with the death taboo in the Monkey; the eighth month, with the death taboo in the Rooster; the ninth month, with the death taboo in the Dog; the tenth month, with the death taboo in the Pig; the eleventh month, with the death taboo in the Rat; or the twelfth month, with the death taboo in the Ox. For these deeply grave taboos and calamities, he beseeches the generals, officials, and soldiers of the True Qi of the Great Dao to compassionately resolve the registers of death and inscribe their names in the registers of life.

Moreover, he fears that this disciple [Name] and his household may be afflicted by the monthly calamities of the Grand Year-Star, with their three hun and seven po souls confined in the northern prison of Mount Tai. Or that the Great Yin Envoys, the Lords of Wind and Rain, may claim to be the Grand Year-Star, the Great Yin, the Great Yang, the Great Generals, the Northern Director of Destinies, the Twelve Monthly Establishments, or assume other official titles, roaming the heavens and earth, followed by demonic soldiers, music, and banners, blowing horns and beating drums, bearing flags and staffs. They may claim to be the spirits of the local altars, the Stove Lord and Lady of the household, the Earth Lord and House Dragon, or the ghosts of soldiers, hunters, or those who died by misadventure, such as Li Ao. These spirits consort with thousands of ghosts and myriad deities, the hundred and twenty kinds of earthly and celestial punishments and calamities, and may come to harm this disciple’s household, causing illness, the departure of essence and qi, the disattachment of hun and po souls, and the persistence of calamities. Whatever they encounter turns to adversity, and official misfortunes arise wantonly. In such dire straits, he is filled with urgent dread, fearing he cannot escape. He pleads for mercy, his plight deserving of compassion.

This servant, overwhelmed by what he has witnessed, humbly risks transgression and prostrates himself to the ground, beseeching the submission of this **Memorial for Urgent Relief, Exorcism, Tallying Lifespans, and Curing Illnesses**, one document in all, to ascend [to the Jade Throne].

chunks.original_text: 天曹，恩惟 太上老君太上丈人，天师女师三师君夫人门下典者五炁君等，留念小臣所上文书，以时上达 天府，乞真炁下流，覆荫弟子某身及家口大小，良贱平安无他，永保元吉，弟子某家大小，所有深灾重障疾病之者，早蒙除差，度脱无余，复连外祥游逸诸鬼，并乞消灭，宅舍安泰，凶神恶鬼远避他方，不相谋议，出入经行，善神扶卫，水火为灭，金石为开，仰衔罔极，谨为上请束方九夷生算君一人，官将百二十人，上请南方八蛮生算君一人，官将百二十人，上请西方六戎生算君一人，官将百二十人，上请北方五狄生算君一人，官将百二十人，上请中央三秦戊己生筹君一人，官将三十九万人，今所请天官君将吏兵，一合来下，主为弟子某身拔出魂魄，恐闭击在其星宫之中，或在角亢氏房心尾箕，斗牛女虚危室壁奎娄，胃勖毕赀参井鬼，柳星张翼辑，□□□□□□□，二十八宿，三十五星官等，一合来下，主为弟子某身及家口大小，上解天罗，下除地网，消灾度厄，断绝外□，复连之鬼，并令破散消灭无余，病者除差，食饮通利，还颜复色，四大调和，平复如本，人口大小良贱等身，各乞扶佑，安隐无他，所向元吉，仰荷重恩，谨为上请正月寅上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请二月卯上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请三月辰上解击大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请四月巳上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请五月午上解击大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请六月未上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请七月申上解击大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请八月酉上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请九月戌上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请十月亥上解击大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请十一月子上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，上请十二月丑上解系大将军一人，兵士十万人来下，今所请十二月解系将军吏兵等，乞愿具官一合来下，为弟子某身及家口大小等，所有深灾重疾，次为除解，或年中之厄，月中之厄，日中之厄，时中之厄，并乞真炁一切除解，超然过度，永保元吉，重请北方上仙解厄治病功曹千二百人，谨请素男素女十二人，谨请南昌宫河洛抽魂拔魄君一人，兵士千二百人，上请天医治病功曹十万人，地医治病功曹十万人，一合来下，主为弟子某身及家口大小，解脱罗网，过灾度厄，拔出三 魂七魄，付与身中，悉令备足，灾厄度脱，病患除差，了了无余，先亡后死外升等鬼，永辟异方，凶人谋议，一切消灭，乞使眠梦真正，宅舍清宁，大小家口，被蒙清吉，安隐无他，伏乞大道真官将吏兵士，为弟子某等，於天地水三官、五岳四渎、三河四海、百鬼牢狱门下，求觅弟子某身及家口大小等，或有年穷算尽之厄，魁纲加临之厄，元辰勾绞之厄，五行相克之厄，上从一厄，乃至九厄百二十刑厄，次乞解除追摄魂魄，付与身中，即令痊差，如不见者，请为约问，先代亡人三丘五墓门下，求觅弟子某身三魂七魄，女三魂十四魄，付与身中，如不见者，约问太山二十四狱之中，求觅某魂魄，付与身中，所有深灾重厄，千病万痛，即蒙除差，千灾万厄，究尽无余，性命完全，平复如本，四支五体，三宫六腑，七窍荣卫，三百六十骨节，千二百形影，万二千精光，五色瑠璃，赤白在身若天仓乏少，益其斗斛，年命短促，加其算禄，有不便者，请为转易，以短为长，以青为黄，当令寿命长延，灾衰永脱，所有病患，一切除断，先亡后死，外□等鬼，回发善心，共相拥护，不相复连，人口平安，住宅清净，出入通泰、所向从心，蒙如所愿，被受重恩，小臣某所请

chunks.original_text: 广成先生杜光庭集 道士悔谢章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜上言，某辞，千生有幸，得充治职，奉宣清法，医治疾病，而以暗劣不晓鬼神之事，不能用心辅助师道，救疗无方，以此获罪，招罹灾考，疾患更互，所为无可，所向不利，肉人轗轲，私心忧惧，告臣自诉，求乞救解，臣备师胤攸，摄是同谨承某辞，冒昧以闻，臣以某领户化民，从来日久，或奉行违失，三气错乱，或功诡逋留，迁赏不达，或福储天藏，不时输送，或乞赐失理，怨恨者众，诸如前罪，非一衅锺考，加以致疾祟，愿为天地水三官考逮，君吏言功举迁，迁上中宫，谒受功赏，署以使曹，无令怨恚，天曹典者，考申功过，垂恩宽宥，效其将来，千愆万咎，一切赦贯，恩惟 太上，分别哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使，正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，首愆谢过，请福禳灾恩章一通，上诣 某曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 道士解过章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，谨案文书，某以顽疏，奉道多违，虽忝法职，宣化无效，民物离散，救疗逋迟，或知而故犯，意短不及，或因真行伪，前却法制、或领化民户，恐动百姓，或吞脏啖罪、私用法物，或口恭心慢、轻傲师法，或称教妄语，驱合虚诈，或追人求钱，以轻作重，或宗室骨肉，不相和顺，或门内父子，更相逆戾，或道义妒，淫乱秽浊，或暮晨骂詈，声干清正，或心恚意怒，三五七九，长短失度，不秉六壬，更用六丙，背弃六癸、动向六丁，行气错误，冒犯天忌，或恃宠自骄，不恤急厄，或见欲心荡，托尊强求，饮酒食肉，淫色盗取，或吏兵有劳，不时举迁，或凶险好斗，持人长短，或值发阴私，评人曲直，或受化道辞，讪露幽密，或娇诈师老，惊怛愚俗，或评论真要，指形名道，或怀挟锣怨，走作考气，或修饰自明，好己恶彼，诸如此罪，二十九条，其尽犯违，为玄司所纠，计愆量过，分足灰灭，大道崇宽，太上贵生，愿垂怜者，乞丐生活，原赦千罪万过之死，以明覆载之重，亦自克责，深修法度，不敢以前为比，恩惟 太上，分别哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使、正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，忏愆悔过，请命祈恩，宝章一通，上诣 某曹，伏须告报，臣诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 道士迁考章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，谨案文书某辞如右，胎生肉人，少不经学，大义不通，前以乐化，制属 大道，荷受殊恩，得充治职，化民领户，出入有年，诚自喜乐，肉人无知，未能报称，诚恐负冰流汗，某伏自惟省，人轻任重，耳目闭塞，在职初浅，不晓科禁，奉行多违，无状所致，以某年月日卒得疾病，未蒙除差，克己思愆，不自分解、惟惧罪过，深积丑恶，上闻 天曹典者遣考，召吏兵下，在某家考治某身，加以楚毒，昼夜考掠，不得休息，呼吸之气，命在丝发，某家大小惶怖，恐不生活，某在职以来，上不敬天地，下不孝父母，不顺师法，多恶少善，多逆少顺，多嗔少喜，触犯天地日月星辰，违背五行王相四时禁忌，穿掘平地，填井塞渎，或壅障水流，断绝道路，伐树杀生，探巢破卵，或阴行贼害，盗取人物，或枉杀旱生怨满道路，或轻慢天地、呼谓无神，或取人财物、抵戾不还，或掩人之善，扬人之恶，或背真妄语，岐咽两舌，咒诅骂詈，颠倒无道，或借使贫人，以利家私，或好色淫通，奸人妇女，或隔戾妒，僧嫉胜己，所为不当，所行昧理，致招重考，收魂缚魄，五毒惨至，分当万死，彰示远近，自知罪重，谨随事首列，不敢藏情，有所遗脱，少得苏息，络绎自改，疏洗肠胃，披析筋骨，不敢以前自比，肉人归命，诚可一辰伤，臣谨承其辞，触冒汤火，拜章上闻，乞赐典者，垂恩料省，肉人以伏以诺、考召君吏有功，愿还
chunks.translated_text:
**Petition of Repentance by Daoist Du Guangting**

**Petition for Atonement and Redress**
This servant [Name], of [such-and-such] dharma rank, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to submit this petition.

This servant, by the grace of a thousand rebirths, has been deemed worthy to hold office, to uphold and proclaim the pure dharma, and to heal the sick. Yet, being dull and unworthy, I remain ignorant of the ways of spirits and gods. I have failed to devote myself to assisting the Dao of my masters, and my remedies have been ineffectual. For this, I have incurred offenses, brought upon myself disasters and afflictions, and suffered recurring illnesses. My endeavors have come to naught, and my path has been fraught with misfortune. As a mortal, I am beset by hardship, and in my private heart, I am filled with dread. I now submit this petition, seeking deliverance and absolution.

As a servant entrusted with the transformation of the people, I have long overseen households. Yet, in my duties, I may have erred in practice, causing the three qi to fall into disorder. My merits may have been falsified or delayed, and rewards may not have been duly conferred. The blessings stored in heaven’s treasury may not have been delivered in time, or my petitions may have been unjust, giving rise to grievances. Such transgressions as these—and others besides—have accumulated, inviting calamities and afflictions, even illness and malevolent influences. I am willing to be examined and seized by the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water. Let the officials and clerks record my merits and recommend my promotion to the Central Palace, where I may receive due rewards and be assigned to a bureau, so that resentment may be dispelled.

May the clerks of the celestial bureaus review my merits and transgressions, extend their grace, and grant me clemency. May all my myriad faults and offenses be pardoned. I implore the Most High to take pity on my foolishness and unworthiness. Through the envoys of the Two Offices, the left and right officials of the Orthodox Unity Merit Clerk, the yin-yang spirit-decision clerks, the chariot-red-tally clerks, the fierce-wind courier post riders, and the memorial-submitting officials—two of each—I humbly submit this petition for [Name], seeking to confess transgressions, atone for faults, and beseech blessings to avert disaster. One petition is hereby presented to [such-and-such] bureau, awaiting response.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

**Petition for Expiation of Transgressions by a Daoist**
This servant [Name], of [such-and-such] dharma rank, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to submit this petition.

Upon reviewing the documents, I find that, though I have been entrusted with the dharma office, my conduct has often violated the Dao. Despite my unworthy position, my proclamations have been ineffectual, the people and creatures have scattered, and my remedies have been delayed. Some transgressions were committed knowingly, while others arose from my limited understanding. I may have feigned authenticity in my practices, vacillated in upholding the dharma, or mismanaged the households under my care, causing distress to the people. I may have embezzled or misused sacred objects, shown outward reverence while harboring disdain in my heart, or slighted the teachings of my masters. I may have made false claims in the name of the teachings, engaged in deceitful schemes, or extorted money from others by exaggerating matters. I may have caused discord among kin, or fostered strife between parents and children. I may have been envious of fellow Daoists, or indulged in impurity and debauchery. I may have cursed or reviled others, disturbing the purity of the Dao, or given in to anger, disrupting the harmony of the three, five, seven, or nine qi. I may have failed to observe the proper measures, neglected the Six Ren, and instead employed the Six Bing, forsaking the Six Gui while invoking the Six Ding, thereby erring in my practice of qi and offending the celestial taboos. I may have grown arrogant due to favor, neglecting those in dire need, or allowed desire to cloud my judgment, exploiting my position to make demands. I may have indulged in wine, meat, lust, or theft. I may have failed to promote deserving officials in a timely manner, or delighted in conflict, spreading rumors about others. I may have exposed others’ secrets, mocked the aged, or alarmed the ignorant. I may have revealed the esoteric teachings, or maligned the true essence of the Dao. I may have harbored grudges, or sought to harm others through malevolent qi. I may have sought to exalt myself while disparaging others.

Such transgressions—twenty-nine in all—have been fully committed, and I stand condemned by the dark bureaus. Were my faults weighed, they would suffice to reduce me to ashes. Yet the Great Dao is vast and merciful, and the Most High values life. I implore your compassion, beseeching life and pardon for my thousand sins and myriad offenses, that the weight of heaven and earth’s grace may be made manifest. Henceforth, I shall strictly adhere to the dharma, never again repeating past errors.

I implore the Most High to take pity on my foolishness and unworthiness. Through the envoys of the Two Offices, the left and right officials of the Orthodox Unity Merit Clerk, the yin-yang spirit-decision clerks, the chariot-red-tally clerks, the fierce-wind courier post riders, and the memorial-submitting officials—two of each—I humbly submit this petition for [Name], seeking to repent of transgressions, atone for faults, and beseech the granting of grace. One precious petition is hereby presented to [such-and-such] bureau, awaiting response.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

**Petition for Reprieve from Examination**
This servant [Name], of [such-and-such] dharma rank, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to submit this petition.

Upon reviewing the documents submitted by [Name], as stated above: born of flesh, I received little learning in my youth and failed to grasp the great principles. Previously, I rejoiced in transformation and was placed under the governance of the Great Dao. By special grace, I was deemed worthy to hold office, overseeing the transformation of the people and managing households for many years. Though I rejoiced in my position, my mortal ignorance prevented me from fulfilling my duties, and I feared my inadequacy would bring shame upon me.

I have reflected upon myself: my abilities are slight, yet my responsibilities are heavy. My senses are dull, and my tenure in office has been brief. Unfamiliar with the regulations, I have often erred in my duties. Thus, on the [Day] day of the [Month] month of the [Year] year, I fell gravely ill, yet have not recovered. I have examined my faults and cannot absolve myself. Fearing my transgressions, I have accumulated much that is shameful. The clerks of the celestial bureaus have been informed and have dispatched officials to examine me. Soldiers have been sent to my home to subject my body to interrogation, inflicting torment day and night without respite. My breath hangs by a thread, and my family trembles in terror, fearing for our lives.

Since taking office, I have failed to revere heaven and earth above, or honor my parents below. I have disobeyed the teachings of my masters, committed many evils and few good deeds, acted with more defiance than compliance, and given in to anger more than joy. I have offended the heavens, earth, sun, moon, and stars, and violated the prohibitions of the five phases, the waxing and waning of the four seasons. I have dug into level ground, filled wells, and blocked waterways. I have obstructed the flow of water, severed roads, felled trees, and killed living beings. I have taken eggs from nests, secretly harmed others, and stolen their possessions. I have wrongfully killed, leaving grievances to fill the roads. I have shown disrespect to heaven and earth, declaring there are no gods. I have taken others’ property and failed to repay my debts. I have concealed others’ virtues and exposed their faults. I have spoken falsely, engaged in duplicity, cursed, reviled, and acted without principle. I have exploited the poor for personal gain, indulged in lust, and violated women. I have been envious, resentful, and jealous of those more accomplished than myself. My actions have been improper, and my conduct has lacked reason. Thus, I have brought upon myself severe examination, the binding of my hun and po souls, and the infliction of the five poisons. I deserve ten thousand deaths, and my crimes are known far and wide. I now confess all my transgressions without concealment, hoping for a moment’s respite to reform myself. I shall purge my innards, dissect my sinews and bones, and never again compare myself to my past self.

As a mortal, I submit my life in earnest. This servant, bearing [Name]’s petition, ventures through boiling waters and scorching fires to present this memorial. I beseech the clerks to extend their grace and review my case. The mortal humbly accepts and complies. May the officials who have examined me be rewarded, and may I be restored.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

chunks.original_text: 天曹、受赏进入中宫、谒署便曹稳职，如常科比，无令怨恨，某虽罪定，应在灰灭，雀鼠贪生，志欲自改，愿蒙原赦，更赐生命，除其愆责，许以后善，以某所苦和差还精复色，气脉调理平复，以为效信，恩惟 太上分别，一辰臣愚劣，谨因二官直使，正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣谨为某求乞，忏除罪咎，保卫病躯，恩章一通，上诣 天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 道士犯箓解谢章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某素下愚，以代务为业，乐化制属，归命诸君丈人道黑，被受大恩，得充治职，佩受仙箓，领户治民，宣扬正教，助国扶命，而某肉人生长浊世，少不经学，不具大义，奉法失中，施行有违，不忠不孝，不慈不仁，父母兄弟，不相敬顺，贪财好色，饮酒食肉、举动所为，违犯箓禁，顷日以来，梦寤参错，所见非常，家中不利，口舌横生，肉人违科犯约，以致轗轲。 心畏一旦，不自过度，谨触冒汤火，贡章上闻，愿请毕汝君一人官将百二十人，主为某解犯箓上禁忌、饮酒、食肉，诸所违负，皆为和解，千罪万过，乞蒙原赦，某辄洗心濯志，改往修来，敢如岁终无他，以为效信，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者、阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，首雪愆尤，保安幻躯，恩章一通，上诣 天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 道士远行章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某素百官子孙，千载有幸，得充治职，赐受天官吏兵，以自营护，非某顽贱所宜，被蒙奉化日浅，无所知识，夙夜战灼，如临深渊，今当到某处，经由崄 远，世弊人伪，鬼气未清，惧寇盗攻劫，行路诣臣自告，求乞上闻，谨为某上请天官兵皇君一人，官将百二十人，摇天动地君九炁君十五万众，左马君官将百二十人，各一合下，与某俱行辟斥奸邪，千凶万恶，县官口舌，不为灾害，吏兵所护，万恶消除，禳却寇盗，通利道路，又请东九夷、南八蛮、西六戎、北五狄、中三秦诸君，各将兵士十万人，及衣铁履刃兵，灭亡水火兵，反甲逆鳞兵百二十万人，九天兵符三十五官君，高麾大鼓赤阳十伐将军兵十万人，及四面真官注炁黄帝君，及营星君官将百二十人，同时来下卫某身，辟除群凶逆恶不轨之事，道中魍魉不正之气，一切消伏、往还安稳，回归之日，为所请官君将吏，言功平等，并所经游郡县，水陆乡亭里域，监察考召诸君，道上二玄三元，四始甲子诸官君，亭传客舍，营署注鬼，四野九野都平君，山林孟长，十二溪女，九江水帝，河伯吕公子等，营护道路，使陆行通易，水行利涉，诸功劳者，至时还赏，不令违失，某蒙恩如愿，以为效信，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神庾吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置吏，驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞祈安，水陆保佑，行藏恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 旧事道中绝於法契阔章

To the Celestial Bureaus,

Upon receiving rewards, may they enter the Central Palace and report to the respective offices to stabilize their positions, following the usual regulations, so as not to incur resentment. Though my sins are already determined and I deserve annihilation, like the sparrow and mouse clinging to life, I aspire to reform. I humbly beg for pardon and the gift of life, absolving my transgressions and faults, permitting future goodness. May the suffering I endure be alleviated, my essence restored, my complexion revived, and my qi and pulses regulated and harmonized as proof of my sincerity. I implore the Most High to discern this.

For a moment, this foolish and inferior servant, through the direct envoys of the Two Offices, the Functionaries of the Orthodox Unity, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot and Scarlet Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Courier Station Masters, and the Memorial-Presenting Officials—each dispatching two attendants—earnestly petitions on behalf of [Name] to confess and absolve sins, safeguard this ailing body.

One memorial is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureaus, awaiting notification.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

**Memorial of a Daoist Priest for the Annulment of Register Violations**

This humble servant, [Name], of such-and-such ordination rank, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to submit this memorial:

I, of lowly and foolish nature, have long been occupied with worldly duties, delighting in transformation and governance, submitting my life to the Lords and Masters of the Dao. Having received great favor, I was entrusted with administrative duties, bestowed with the immortal registers, and charged with overseeing households and guiding the people. I was to propagate the true teachings and assist the nation in sustaining its mandate. Yet, born and raised in this impure world, I lacked learning from youth, failed to grasp profound principles, and in upholding the Dao, lost the mean in practice. My conduct was disloyal, unfilial, unkind, and unbenevolent. I disrespected and disobeyed my parents and siblings, coveted wealth and lust, indulged in wine and meat, and in all my actions, violated the prohibitions of the registers. Recently, my dreams and waking hours have been disturbed, my visions abnormal, my household plagued with misfortune, and my words met with strife. I have transgressed the statutes and breached the covenants, bringing upon myself this adversity.

Fearing sudden calamity and unable to endure further, I venture through boiling waters and scorching fires to present this memorial. I humbly request that the Lord Bi Yu dispatch one official and one hundred twenty attendants to absolve my violations of the register’s prohibitions—my consumption of wine and meat, and all my transgressions—reconciling them all. For my thousand sins and ten thousand faults, I beg for pardon. I shall purify my heart and renew my resolve, reforming the past and cultivating the future. Should I complete this year without further incident, let it serve as proof of my sincerity. I implore the Most High to discern this.

Through the direct envoys of the Two Offices, the Functionaries of the Orthodox Unity, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot and Scarlet Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Courier Station Masters, and the Memorial-Presenting Officials—each dispatching two attendants—I earnestly petition on behalf of [Name] to confess and absolve faults, safeguarding this ephemeral body.

One memorial is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureaus, awaiting notification.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

**Memorial of a Daoist Priest for Safe Travel**

This humble servant, [Name], of such-and-such ordination rank, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to submit this memorial:

I, a descendant of the myriad officials, have been fortunate across a thousand generations to be entrusted with administrative duties and bestowed with the celestial officials and soldiers for my protection—a favor far beyond what my stubborn and base nature deserves. Having received this transformation for but a short time, I remain ignorant and unenlightened, trembling day and night as if standing at the edge of an abyss. Now, as I journey to [such-and-such place], traversing perilous and distant paths, where the world is corrupt, people deceitful, and ghostly qi yet uncleansed, I fear bandits and robbers may attack and plunder. Thus, I submit this memorial to make my plea known.

I humbly request the Celestial Officials and August Lords—one Heavenly Official Soldier Lord, one hundred twenty attendants; the Nine Qi Lords with their fifteen myriad hosts; the Left Horse Lord with one hundred twenty attendants; each to descend in unison to accompany me, repelling and expelling all wickedness and rebellion. May the thousand evils and ten thousand ills, the slanders of officials, and all disasters be averted. Under the protection of the soldiers, may all evils be dispelled, bandits warded off, and roads made passable.

I further request the Lords of the Eastern Nine Yi, Southern Eight Man, Western Six Rong, Northern Five Di, and Central Three Qin—each leading one hundred thousand soldiers, clad in iron, wielding blades, and commanding the armies of water, fire, reversed armor, and inverted scales—along with one million two hundred thousand troops. May the Thirty-Five Lords of the Nine Heavens’ Talismans, the Great Banners and Drums of the Red Yang Ten Punitive Generals with their ten myriad soldiers, and the True Officials of the Four Directions, the Qi-Infusing Yellow Emperor Lords, and the Camp Star Lords with their one hundred twenty attendants descend simultaneously to guard my person, repelling all malevolent and rebellious forces, and dispelling the unruly qi of specters and demons along the way. May all be subdued, my journey safe, and my return secure.

Upon my return, I shall duly report the merits of the officials, generals, and soldiers who accompanied me, ensuring equitable recognition. For all the commanderies, counties, waterways, and land routes I traverse, the lodges and inns I stay in, and the encampments and registries of ghosts, I beseech the supervising and examining Lords—the Two Mysteries, Three Origins, Four Beginnings, and Jiazi Officials of the roads; the Warden Lords of the post stations and guesthouses; the Camp and Registry Lords of wandering spirits; the Lords of the Four Wilds and Nine Regions; the Elders of the Mountains and Forests; the Twelve Stream Maidens; the Water Emperors of the Nine Rivers; and the River Earls and Lords of Lü—all to safeguard the roads, ensuring smooth passage on land and safe crossing on water.

May all who labor be rewarded in due time, without omission or error. Should I receive this favor and fulfill my wish, let it serve as proof of my sincerity. I implore the Most High to discern this.

Through the direct envoys of the Two Offices, the Functionaries of the Orthodox Unity, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot and Scarlet Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Couriers, and the Memorial-Presenting Officials—each dispatching two attendants—I earnestly petition on behalf of [Name] for safe passage on land and water.

One memorial is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureaus, awaiting notification.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

The Dharma-Ranked Servant of [Surname], with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates, bows twice, and respectfully submits:

This foolish descendant of mine, though born of humble lineage, has long cultivated the virtuous Dao. In former times, when the Han dynasty’s fortune shifted, the rites and teachings flowed freely. Though I remained in the secular world, I did not forsake the pure Dharma. Yet, dwelling near lowly officials, my affairs became entangled with the perverse. My own dullness and ignorance left my merits unworthy of record, and so I was assailed by malevolent spirits. Of late, my household has suffered manifold afflictions—illnesses, the death of servants, and the depletion of wealth. Searching my conduct for fault, I cannot discern the cause. Though I sought mercy through the Dao, I have not received its sheltering grace. Thus, I now submit this memorial, humbly beseeching Your compassionate review.

My family has served the Dao for generations and ought to be held in esteem by all. Yet, though we dwell beneath the vast covering of Heaven and Earth, we have encountered misfortune and adversity. I suspect my actions have strayed from the harmonious Dao, inverting the natural order and mingling with the common herd. Though the Three Origins and Four Beginnings grow ever more exalted, the myriad spirits of the lower realms have become the arbiters of my fate. Even in this single delusion, I cannot free myself. I implore Your mercy to absolve all my transgressions, that from this day forth, my path may be prosperous, my illnesses dispelled, and my household secure in peace and abundance.

I implore the Most High to discern this humble servant’s plight. Through the direct envoys of the Two Offices, the Functionaries of the Orthodox Unity, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot and Scarlet Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Couriers, and the Memorial-Presenting Officials—each dispatching two attendants—I earnestly petition on behalf of [Name] to dispel calamity, safeguard my family, and restore well-being.

One memorial is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureaus, awaiting notification.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

**Memorial to Sever Slander on All Sides**

The Dharma-Ranked Servant of [Surname], with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates, bows twice, and respectfully submits:

I humbly observe that this unworthy descendant, born and raised in rustic ignorance, was never versed in the rites of the Dao. By mere happenstance, I was appointed to this office, where I must now account before the Celestial, Terrestrial, and Aquatic Bureaus. As a mortal of dull wit, my tenure has been brief, and my transgressions many. Overwhelmed with dread, I know not where to turn.

I prostrate and bow twice again. Since the day and month I received the Essential Words of the True Unity, my dim understanding has failed to fully grasp the methods of nurturing the spirit and receiving qi. Yet, I have dutifully served the secular world, where many turn their backs on the Dao, slandering their masters and reviling the Way. Their tongues wag ceaselessly, each claiming righteousness, while I, guilty of untold offenses, deserve to be shattered and ground to dust. I dare not hope for life, yet by the grace of the Venerable Lords, I prostrate myself and submit this memorial.

I humbly beseech the Invincible Azure Mysterious Lord to dispatch a host of one million soldiers to suppress slanderous tongues, the ghosts of curses and oaths. I further entreat the Southern Guardian and the Six Stellar Lords, along with their one hundred twenty generals, and the Thirty Billion Celestial Maidens of the Zhou Tian, to descend at once and apprehend all who persist in malice, rebellion, scheming, and slander. Let them visit every household, bringing reconciliation and sealing away the venom of perverse and wicked tongues. May all such enmity dissolve at once, as proof of this covenant.

Let the generals, officers, and soldiers, along with the stellar guardians of every quarter, infuse their qi to oversee and examine the merits of these divine envoys. Should they fail in their duty, may they be held accountable. I beg that the thousand sins and ten thousand transgressions I have committed, past and present, be wholly absolved. I shall exert my utmost effort, sparing no devotion, to ensure peace and security, as proof of my sincerity.

I implore the Compassionate Father and Mother to take pity on this foolish servant. Through the direct envoys of the Two Offices, the Functionaries of the Orthodox Unity, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot and Scarlet Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Couriers, and the Memorial-Presenting Officials—each dispatching two attendants—I earnestly petition to silence all slanderous lips and safeguard my person.

One memorial is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureaus, awaiting notification.

This servant, with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to make this known.

---

**Memorial to Stabilize Qi and Resolve Illness**

The Dharma-Ranked Servant of [Surname], with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates, bows twice, and respectfully submits:

This lowly descendant, born of a lineage that has long served the lower officials, inherited from my ancestors the practice of offering libations to the myriad spirits. Yet, we have not received their blessings; instead, we have suffered misfortune and calamity. Thus, we entrusted our fate to the Great Dao to preserve our lives. Since pledging ourselves to its service, we have been graced with profound favor—our household has known peace and stability, a cause for both joy and trepidation.

Yet, as a mortal, my conduct has often strayed. Since the year and month of [Date], I have known no respite. My limbs grow heavy, my rest is fitful, and my waking hours are troubled. In dreams, I wander through quiet chambers or ruined halls, as though receiving guests, or lie abed as if scaling mountains, crossing peaks, riding chariots, or sailing ships. At times, I am consumed by resentment or joy, my emotions unchecked. At others, I speak in the voices of spirits, proclaiming their authority, or rail against my household, recounting the affairs of the common folk. Sometimes, I am seized by sorrow, my actions without reason. This affliction lingers, waxing and waning, leaving my flesh wasted and my bones emaciated. My heart trembles at the thought of sudden demise, fearing I may be ensnared by malevolent spirits, led astray, and bound in delusion.

Turning inward, I examine my conduct. Though I bear the sacred registers and wear the emblems of purity, my sincerity is faint, and my devotion divided. I have failed to repel evil and dispel harm. Thus, I humbly submit this memorial, beseeching the Twelve Great Generals of the Mysterious Elder and their one hundred twenty generals to descend upon my person, seizing the rebellious ghosts of the Three Bureaus and the spirits of the myriad elders who claim divine authority and emerge from the Dao. May they be dispersed at once.

If my bones and destiny align with Heaven’s decree, and I am granted recovery, I shall receive the central qi. I implore Your discernment to distinguish truth from falsehood, that the malevolent spirits and perverse influences may be dispelled, and my qi restored to purity, as proof of this covenant.

chunks.original_text: 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞四肢康泰，动履清安恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首以闻。 道士天地水三官手书箓状章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某郡县乡里男女生某甲，年如干岁，谨条手书首罪，簿状如左簿，状之法一事一条，不得华辞文过，藏重出轻，若首而不尽，考官不解，一事以上，甲年如干，时所犯罪过，某年月日某时，某郡某县某里男女生某甲，年如干岁，户口如干，某奉法违科，以某月某日卒得疾病苦厄是云云，至今不差，恐不生活，谨操手书录状，诣 泰清玄元无上三天无极大道太上老君，太上丈人都官君考行状，六质六壳，二十四官君，天师嗣师系师三师君门下将吏所在郡县治中，四面注气，监察考召四君，某今疾病，手书自证，首写过咎轻重好丑种数，名列如牒，乞丐生活，疾病除差，当奉承手书，奉行孝道，案如师法，当慈仁忠孝，敬老爱少，收孤养寡，救活贫弱，所在师家，投理矜使，百事在前，当与师家共同腹目，不得隔戾（女＋自）妬，岐咽两舌，背真妄语，自作一法，更相说道，匿丑说善，匿重说轻，不首情实，一旦违负手书，以身口数谢天地水三官，不敢自怨，谨请东九夷君，南八蛮君，西六戎君，北五狄君，中央三秦衣铁履刃君，各十二人，官将百万众，逆毛错鳞兵，东方青帝，南方赤帝，西方白帝，北方黑帝，中央黄帝，青龙白虎，朱雀玄武，勾陈等，皆共检察，肉人自欲求生，乞丐存活，奉行师道，传千万世，咸使天下万民已在道者，未在道者，皆使闻知，手书自证，从道取信，事在久远，不能尽悉，重复思省，所得续上，三日一期，如蒙省察，慈父圣母，哀怜元元，自今以后，络绎自改，荡胃推筋折骨，不敢以前自比，乞丐生活，某今谨自手书，画一为信 上言，臣某胎生肉人，枯骨子孙，少不经学，无所知别，得充治职，忝为祭酒，当助天师布演道炁，助国扶命医治疾病，臣受性六弊，为人间钝，不能宣扬道炁，劝善化恶，夙夜战栗，无心自安，某同气祭酒男女生，某甲奉道有违无状，所致身被灾病，连日累月，不觉损差，呼吸之气，命在丝发，思过自责，不能自解，穷连处顿，无所归凭，今来诣治，告臣首写身中前后罪过，从年七岁以来所犯善恶好丑，轻重条列如牒，乞从 大道，更受生活，肉人归诚，在可怜伤，谨腾某辞，触冒汤火，伏地拜章，辞达以后，分当万坐，诚惭诚恐，负冰流汗，愿乞典者案其簿状，下天官地官水官一百二十曹，随事原赦，还算复纪，哀宥既往，责以将来，肉人已诺，首写情实，考吏所考，事蒙立应，实有验者，宜加迁赏，以报其劳，谨当一切，都为天官地官水官考召君将吏，从考吏兵等，悉为言功举迁，加秩等数，如天曹科比随章上诣，各归本曹，列功多少，中宫谒署便曹稳职，无令失意，有怨恨者，某魂魄击在天曹，考对日久，重乞原赦，某三魂七魄还附某身，所苦除差，以为效信，愿慈父圣母，大恩省察分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，度脱厄难，保卫形躯恩章一通，上诣
chunks.translated_text:
Most High, in Your discernment, take pity upon this foolish and inferior servant. Through the mediation of the Two Bureaus’ Direct Envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Envoys, the Yin-Yang Spirit Judgment Clerks, the Scarlet Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Gale-Wind Courier Post Horses, and the Memorial-Offering Clerks—each dispatched in pairs—I, your servant, humbly beseech on behalf of [Name] a memorial for the blessing of limb-strength and well-being, that every movement may proceed in pure peace. This petition is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau, awaiting Your decree.

I prostrate myself in reverence and awe, kowtowing to make this known.

---

**Memorial of the Handwritten Register to the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water**

Your subordinate, [Name], holding the dharma-rank, prostrates in reverence and awe, kowtowing twice, and respectfully declares:

I, [Name], a man/woman of [Prefecture, County, Village], aged [Number] years, now set forth in handwritten form the sins of my past, itemized as follows. Each matter is recorded separately, without embellishment or concealment, omitting nothing, whether grave or slight. Should any transgression remain unconfessed, or should the examining officials find ambiguity, let each offense be listed thus:

In the year [Year], at [Month, Day, Hour], I, [Name], a man/woman of [Prefecture, County, Village], aged [Number] years, with [Number] household members, having violated the precepts of the Dao, fell ill on [Month, Day] and have suffered affliction to this day, with no sign of recovery. Fearing for my life, I now submit this handwritten register and memorial, respectfully presented to the Most High, the Primordial and Boundless Lord of the Three Heavens, the Supreme Dao, the Most High Lord Lao, the Lord of the Capital Bureau, the Examiners of Conduct, the Six Essences and Six Shells, the Twenty-Four Bureau Lords, the Celestial Masters, their Heirs, and Lineage Masters, as well as the generals and clerks under their command in the prefectures and counties. May the Four Lords of the Four Directions, who oversee the infusion of qi and the scrutiny of deeds, examine this servant’s illness. I have handwritten this confession, listing each transgression—its gravity, nature, and number—as recorded in the attached register. I beg for life, for the alleviation of my illness, and vow henceforth to uphold this handwritten pledge, practicing filial devotion in accordance with the Master’s teachings. I shall cultivate kindness, loyalty, and filial piety, honor the aged, cherish the young, care for orphans, support widows, and succor the poor and weak. In all matters, I shall submit to the Master’s household, treating their affairs as my own, sharing their joys and sorrows. I shall not sow discord, engage in slander, speak falsely, or devise private doctrines. I shall not conceal faults while praising virtues, nor downplay grave sins while confessing minor ones. Should I fail to fully disclose the truth, or should I violate this pledge, I shall offer my body and speech in repentance to the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water, accepting all consequences without complaint.

I now invoke the Lords of the Eastern Nine Yi, the Southern Eight Man, the Western Six Rong, the Northern Five Di, and the Central Three Qin—each with twelve attendants and a host of one million soldiers, the Reverse-Hair and Cross-Scale Warriors—as well as the Azure Emperor of the East, the Vermilion Emperor of the South, the White Emperor of the West, the Black Emperor of the North, the Yellow Emperor of the Center, the Azure Dragon, the White Tiger, the Vermilion Bird, the Dark Warrior, and Gouchen, to collectively examine my case. As a mortal seeking life, I beg for survival, vowing to uphold the Master’s Way and transmit it for ten thousand generations. May all under Heaven—those already in the Dao and those yet to enter—hear of this handwritten confession and take it as proof of my commitment to the Way. Though the matter is long-standing and I cannot recall every detail, I shall reflect deeply and submit further confessions as they come to mind, every three days. Should You, Merciful Father and Holy Mother, take pity on the common people and grant Your scrutiny, I shall reform henceforth, purging my past errors. Even if my stomach is scoured, my sinews stretched, and my bones broken, I shall never again compare myself to my former self. I beg for life.

I now solemnly handwrite this pledge as proof.

---

I, your servant, a mortal of flesh and bone, descendant of withered remains, untrained in learning and ignorant of discernment, have been unworthily appointed to the office of Libationer. My duty is to assist the Celestial Master in propagating the qi of the Dao, aiding the nation, sustaining life, and healing illness. Yet, burdened by the Six Defilements, I am dull-witted and have failed to propagate the Dao’s qi, exhort virtue, or transform evil. Day and night, I tremble in fear, unable to find peace.

Your servant, [Name], a fellow Libationer of the same qi, having violated the Dao and brought disorder upon himself, now suffers from prolonged illness, worsening by the day. My breath hangs by a thread, and in self-reproach, I find no relief. Exhausted and without refuge, I now come before the court to confess in writing all my past sins—good and evil, grave and slight—from the age of seven to the present, itemized as in the attached register. I beg the Great Dao to grant me life anew.

As a mortal, I turn to You in sincerity, hoping for Your compassion. I now submit this plea, braving fire and boiling water, prostrating to present this memorial. Should my words reach You, I shall accept my fate among the myriad beings. Overwhelmed with shame and fear, my sweat flows like melting ice.

I beseech the examining officials to review my register and submit it to the One Hundred Twenty Bureaus of the Heavenly, Earthly, and Water Officials. May they pardon my past transgressions, restore my fate and destiny, and grant clemency for what has passed while holding me accountable for the future. As a mortal, I have pledged to fully confess the truth. Should the examining clerks’ scrutiny yield immediate and verifiable results, let them be duly rewarded for their labor.

I now respectfully submit this memorial to all the Examiners, Generals, and Clerks of the Heavenly, Earthly, and Water Bureaus, as well as the soldiers under their command, to report their merits and recommend promotions in rank, in accordance with the statutes of the Celestial Bureau. Let each return to their respective bureau, where their accomplishments shall be recorded. The Central Palace shall review and approve their ranks, ensuring no grievances remain.

Should any resentment linger, let my hun and po be detained in the Celestial Bureau for prolonged interrogation. I humbly beg for pardon, that my three hun and seven po may return to my body, my suffering be alleviated, and this be taken as proof of Your efficacy.

May the Merciful Father and Holy Mother, in Your great compassion, examine and discern my plea. Take pity upon this foolish and inferior servant. Through the mediation of the Two Bureaus’ Direct Envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Envoys, the Yin-Yang Spirit Judgment Clerks, the Scarlet Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Gale-Wind Courier Post Horses, and the Memorial-Offering Clerks—each dispatched in pairs—I, your servant, humbly beseech on behalf of [Name] a memorial for deliverance from distress and the protection of his/her body. This petition is respectfully submitted.

chunks.original_text: 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 伏誓从道乞丐－生章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，臣某昔以有幸，得染清化，被受重恩，赐某仙官吏兵以自营护，出入积年，大小端心，诚自喜乐，某受性顽塞，不明天地禁忌，奉行多愆，为真官考气所纠，以某日月被考，疾病积如干日，体羸气乏，命在旦夕，大小惶怖，恐不生活，归命 大道，伏罪首过，乞丐生活，仍於某家私自跪誓，言当改过为善，改逆为顺，伏诺从道，不敢前却，唯乞原赦，假延日月，令得视息，当精思身中所犯过罪，随事列首，肉人诚浅，未蒙哀放，所苦沉滞，日有增剧，阖门大小，分为灰土，匍匐诣治，告臣求哀，乞丐生命，更自修华，差愈之后，要当辅助师道，服膺法宪，除故自新，唯善是从，不敢有违，臣以愚暗，宣化无功，未审其罪过轻重，身被何考而委顿积时，不蒙差损，肉人元元，欲自改悔，雀鼠贪生，诚可怜伤，谨冒犯清正，触蹈汤火，为某拜章一通， 上诣 三天司命曹，唯愿上官典者，为考校天曹文书，计功除过，和解考气，谨请九天君一人，官将一百二十人，为某解罪逮召，上通中宫各署，便曹稳职，还某魂魄，令附身形，由来所行，无善可纪，积算右宫，唯罪是书，有过无功，无以相补者，乞特原其万罪，赐其一生，效其将来，责以后善，若某不负言则，考化为功，如其背违治之不脱，臣不胜肉人危急，干冒上闻，伏以悚惧，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，忏除罪咎，坚固道心，恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 疾困延命章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某荒俗子孙，胎生肉人，乐化奉治，以自生活，而某多愆，以延灾祸，昨得疾病，百毒备至，从来转久，有增无损，今者沉困，示有气息，累因众官，乞请罪过，脆义信誓，未蒙垂恩，肉人怔营，无复心胆，分翳灰土，永毕天地泉壤，臣备给驱使，奉宣慈化，当助皇老，扶危救厄起疾，臣之常职和愍，肉人命在丝发，谨冒罪拜章，愿请南昌官中延命君五人，官将百二十人，一合下北诣玄阴御女官，拔出某垂终之命，解其万罪，从一至九，以度道数，又请寿命君保命君拔命君三官，各从百二十人下，为某请丐生命，三月一时，三岁一期，要以某得生活，以为效信，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神央吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，消除疾病增益年龄恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 请命章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某疾病云云，有自危笃，考己思愆，不自分别，比诣众治，首写求哀，而某疾病沉困，未蒙轻差，肉人忧惶，恐为灰土，告臣自诉，求乞上闻，臣以愚蒙备承，人乏不胜，肉人凭恃之情，谨冒清严，拜章以闻，案其疾苦，弥时有增无损，必有深重匿罪，事在难赦，或某命衰运终，应归泉壤，诚非臣顽浅所可干冒，仰惟
chunks.translated_text:
To the Celestial Bureau, I humbly await your report. With utmost reverence and awe, I bow my head to the ground, prostrate myself, and kowtow twice to make this known.

I vow to follow the Dao and beseech for a petition of life. The ordained servant of the dharma-rank, [Name], with utmost reverence and awe, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and kowtows twice to address this: I, your servant, once by fortune, was graced with pure transformation and received profound kindness, bestowed with the rank of immortal official and celestial soldiers for my protection. For years, in all matters great and small, I have maintained a sincere heart, truly rejoicing in this. Yet, my nature is stubborn and dull, ignorant of the prohibitions of Heaven and Earth. My conduct has been riddled with transgressions, and I have been investigated by the true officials for my qi. On such-and-such a day and month, I was interrogated, and my illness has persisted for countless days. My body is emaciated, my qi depleted, and my life hangs by a thread. In great fear and dread, I fear I may not survive. I surrender my life to the Great Dao, confess my sins, and beg for life. I have privately knelt in my home and vowed to reform my wrongs, turn from rebellion to obedience, and pledge to follow the Dao without retreat. I only beg for pardon, to extend my days, and allow me to breathe. I shall diligently reflect on the transgressions I have committed and enumerate them one by one. Yet, my mortal understanding is shallow, and I have not received mercy. My suffering lingers, worsening day by day. My entire household, young and old, faces annihilation. I crawl to seek remedy, imploring your servant to beg for mercy and beseech for my life. I vow to cultivate myself anew. Once recovered, I shall assist in the Dao of the Master, uphold the laws and statutes, cast off the old and embrace the new, and follow only goodness without fail.

I, in my foolishness and ignorance, have failed to propagate transformation and do not know the severity of my sins, nor the nature of the punishment that has left me debilitated for so long without relief. As a mortal, I am desperate to repent, yet like a sparrow or mouse, I cling to life—truly pitiable. With trepidation, I dare to offend the pure and upright, braving boiling water and fire, to present this petition on behalf of [Name]. I humbly submit it to the Three Heavens’ Bureau of Life and Destiny. May the esteemed officials examine the celestial records, calculate merits to offset transgressions, and reconcile the punitive qi. I respectfully request one Lord of the Nine Heavens and one hundred twenty officials and generals to absolve my sins and lift the summons. May this reach the various bureaus of the Central Palace, ensuring stable office and the return of my hun and po to my body.

In all my past conduct, there is no goodness to record. My deeds are tallied in the Right Palace, with only sins inscribed. My transgressions abound, and my merits are nonexistent—nothing to offset them. I beg for special pardon of all my sins and the gift of my life. I shall prove myself in the future, held accountable for my future goodness. If I do not betray my words, may my punishment be transformed into merit. If I violate this and remain unabsolved, I, in my mortal peril, dare to bring this to your attention. Overwhelmed with fear, I rely on the Most High to discern and take pity on this foolish and inferior servant. Through the mediation of the Two Bureaus’ Direct Envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Envoys, the Yin-Yang Spirit Judgment Clerks, the Scarlet Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Gale-Wind Courier Post Horses, and the Memorial-Offering Clerks—each dispatched in pairs—I, your servant, humbly beseech on behalf of [Name] for the absolution of sins and the fortification of my Dao-heart. This petition is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau, and I humbly await your report. With utmost reverence and awe, I bow my head to the ground, prostrate myself, and kowtow twice to make this known.

**Petition for Prolonging Life in Dire Illness**
The ordained servant of the dharma-rank, [Name], with utmost reverence and awe, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and kowtows twice to address this: I am a crude and vulgar descendant, a mortal born of flesh, who delights in transformation and governance to sustain my life. Yet, my many transgressions have prolonged my calamities. Recently, I fell ill, afflicted by a hundred poisons. The condition has worsened over time, with no relief. Now, I am gravely debilitated, barely clinging to life. I have repeatedly implored the various officials, confessed my sins, and made solemn vows, yet I have not received mercy. As a mortal, I am filled with dread, my heart and courage lost. I am resigned to becoming dust, forever consigned to the Yellow Springs. I, who am tasked with serving and propagating the compassionate transformation, should assist the August Elders in rescuing the perilous, healing the sick, and aiding those in distress—this is my constant duty and my compassionate concern. Yet, my mortal life hangs by a thread. With trepidation, I dare to submit this petition, beseeching five Lords of Longevity from the Southern Prosperity Bureau, along with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to descend together to the Palace of the Dark Yin’s Imperial Concubine. May they extract my fading life, absolve all my sins from first to ninth, and fulfill the Dao’s reckoning. I further request the Lord of Lifespan, the Lord of Life Protection, and the Lord of Life Extraction—three officials, each accompanied by one hundred twenty attendants—to descend and plead for my life, once every three months for three years. I vow that if I am granted life, it shall serve as proof of your efficacy. I rely on the Most High to discern and take pity on this foolish and inferior servant. Through the mediation of the Two Bureaus’ Direct Envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Envoys, the Yin-Yang Spirit Judgment Clerks, the Scarlet Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Gale-Wind Courier Post Horses, and the Memorial-Offering Clerks—each dispatched in pairs—I, your servant, humbly beseech on behalf of [Name] for the elimination of illness and the augmentation of years. This petition is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau, and I humbly await your report. With utmost reverence and awe, I bow my head to the ground, prostrate myself, and kowtow twice to make this known.

**Petition for Life**
The ordained servant of the dharma-rank, [Name], with utmost reverence and awe, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and kowtows twice to address this: My illness is grave, and I am in critical danger. Reflecting on my transgressions, I cannot discern their nature. I have repeatedly sought remedies, confessed, and begged for mercy. Yet, my illness remains severe, with no alleviation. As a mortal, I am filled with dread, fearing I shall become dust. I implore your servant to bring this to your attention. In my foolishness and ignorance, burdened by human frailty, I rely on this plea. With trepidation, I dare to offend the pure and stern, submitting this petition to make this known. My suffering has only worsened over time, with no relief. There must be deeply concealed and grave sins, or perhaps my life’s fate is at its end, and I am bound for the Yellow Springs. Truly, this is not something my stubborn and shallow self can presume to address. I can only look up and rely...
