chunks.original_text: 太上，慈仁好生恶杀、罪无轻重，输道必赦，绿恃广润含育之施，是以敢触汤火，思效毛发，愿垂矜省，某有识以来，万没之罪，谨请南上君一人，官将百二十人，为某开生门益寿命，又请南昌君一人，官将百二十人，周诣八极之中，星度历纪，脱某死籍，还年益寿，使泉壤之躯，得蒙更生，若某家有强（歹＋羊）不祭之鬼，因衰乘隙，缠绵某身，必固中伤者，愿请刚武敢健严能吏兵百二十人一合下，收摄断截，分别真伪，皆使罢散，令生死区别，各得其所，愿章达日，为臣立效，某若蒙差，言功举迁，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞请命，祈恩保安病患，恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 疾病丐过请命章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，谨按某昔以归化，制属道炁，受恩端等，以自劝勉，肉人罪积，招致重考，疾病云云，思愆首过，冒罪以闻，臣以某月日，为某启请治病功曹，天医太医，辅助医吏，典治某身田臣间乏，精诚无感，某所苦转更增剧，命如丝发，大小狼狈，无复肝胆，不胜所见，谨重拜章，请功曹使者，四方胡越氐羌驿骑，径诣安昌宫中，为某上请护命君、延命君、南上君，三君官将各百二十人，为某削除死籍，更定生名，三月一时，得蒙度脱，臣触死冒责，罪当万坐，乞丐原赦，以某生活为效，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神央吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞保安病证，增益寿龄，恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 困急日中上请命章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某素下官子孙，遭值有幸， 大道开化，好乐清正，操信入法，系命三天，诚自荣慰，而某愚秽，奉气失和，身被病苦，某处痛，命在转烛，从道求哀，未蒙除差，日更增剧，恐为灰土，肉人惶怖，怔忪不能自勉，诣臣诉辞，求乞救护，臣辄省某所疾，甚为危殆，或犯罪弥结，不可哀赦，或天年终尽，在於漏刻，臣伏以 大道真炁，含育群生，能使枯槁之骨，更受血气之荣，临冬之木，再有春葩之晖，回柩起死，唯在垂恩，绿将广润，乞贷某命，谨重烦请南昌宫中延命君五人，官将百二十人，北诣玄阴御女宫，请赎某形躯，使垂绝之命，蒙更生之恩，上祟皇老神气之高，下施雀鼠贪生之愿，恩惟 三师省察，分别求哀，臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞，保卫病躯增延禄算，恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 禁魂魄章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再 拜 上言，某制属·
chunks.translated_text:
To the Most High,

Whose compassion cherishes life and abhors killing, whose mercy pardons all sins, great or small, so long as one submits to the Dao—relying on the boundless grace of nurturing and sustaining, I dare to brave boiling water and scorching fire, aspiring to offer even the smallest service. I humbly beseech your compassionate review: since the dawn of my awareness, my sins have been myriad and profound. I earnestly petition the Southern Supreme Lord, accompanied by one hundred and twenty officials and generals, to open the Gate of Life and augment my years; and the Lord of Southern Prosperity, with one hundred and twenty officials and generals, to traverse the eight directions, measure the stars, and cross the celestial cycles, that my name may be stricken from the register of death and my lifespan extended. May this body, fated for the Yellow Springs, be granted rebirth.

Should malevolent spirits—unappeased and unpropitiated—exploit my weakness to cling to my form and inflict grievous harm, I beseech the dispatch of one hundred and twenty stalwart, valiant, and resolute officers and soldiers to seize, sever, and discern truth from falsehood, dispersing all such entities. Let the living and the dead be clearly distinguished, each restored to their rightful place. May this petition reach the light of day, and may my plea be answered.

Should I recover, I vow to proclaim your merit and seek advancement in service. I implore the Most High to discern and pity my foolishness and inadequacy. Through the intercession of the two official envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendants, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot-Inspecting Red Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Post Station Couriers, and the Memorial-Submitting Officers—each pair dispatched—I, your servant, humbly petition for the preservation of life and the alleviation of suffering. This memorial, one copy, is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau. I await your decree with reverence.

A Petition for Pardon and Life
Your subordinate of such-and-such rank and name, with utmost trepidation, prostrates and kowtows, bowing twice to submit this plea.

I humbly state: Having once submitted to the Dao and aligned with its qi, I received boundless grace, which I strove to emulate. Yet my sins have accumulated, inviting severe retribution. My illness, as previously described, has driven me to reflect on my transgressions and confess my faults, daring to submit this plea despite my guilt.

On such-and-such a day, I invoked the Merit Officers for healing, the Celestial Physicians, the Earthly Physicians, and the assisting medical clerks to attend to my bodily afflictions. Yet my sincerity has failed to move them, and my suffering has only worsened. My life hangs by a thread, and I am utterly undone, devoid of even the courage of liver and gall. Overwhelmed by what I witness, I dare to submit this second petition, beseeching the Merit Officers and the couriers of the four directions—Hu, Yue, Di, and Qiang—to proceed directly to the Palace of Peaceful Prosperity. There, I implore the Lord of Life Protection, the Lord of Longevity, and the Southern Supreme Lord—each accompanied by one hundred and twenty officials and generals—to expunge my name from the register of death and inscribe it anew in the book of life. May I, once every three months, be granted deliverance.

I have braved death and defied reproach, deserving ten thousandfold punishment. Yet I beg for pardon, offering my recovery as proof of your mercy. I implore the Most High to discern and pity my foolishness and inadequacy. Through the intercession of the two official envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendants, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot-Inspecting Red Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Post Station Couriers, and the Memorial-Submitting Officers—each pair dispatched—I, your servant, humbly petition for the preservation of health and the augmentation of my years. This memorial, one copy, is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau. I await your decree with reverence.

A Midday Petition for Life in Dire Distress
Your subordinate of such-and-such rank and name, with utmost trepidation, prostrates and kowtows, bowing twice to submit this plea.

I humbly state: I, a lowly descendant of an official lineage, have been fortunate to witness the flourishing of the Great Dao, delighting in its purity and rectitude. Embracing faith and entering its law, I bound my fate to the Three Heavens, a source of profound honor and comfort. Yet my foolishness and impurity have caused me to fail in harmonizing with the qi, and my body is afflicted with suffering. My pain is such that my life flickers like a candle in the wind. Though I have sought mercy from the Dao, my illness remains unalleviated, growing worse by the day. Fearful of becoming dust, I am filled with dread and unable to compose myself. I turn to you, my lord, to plead for salvation.

Upon reviewing my condition, I find it perilous indeed. Perhaps my sins are too deeply entwined for pardon, or my allotted years have reached their final moments. Yet I recall that the true qi of the Great Dao nurtures all beings, capable of restoring vitality to withered bones and reviving the bloom of spring upon winter-stricken trees. To raise the dead from their coffins requires only your grace. Relying on your boundless compassion, I beg for the extension of my life.

I earnestly beseech the five Lords of Longevity in the Palace of Southern Prosperity, each accompanied by one hundred and twenty officials and generals, to journey north to the Palace of the Dark Yin and the Jade Maidens. There, I implore them to redeem my form, that my nearly severed life may be granted the mercy of rebirth. May your virtue ascend to honor the lofty spirits of the august elders and descend to fulfill the yearning for life even in the lowliest of creatures. I implore the Three Masters to review and discern my plea.

In my foolishness and inadequacy, I rely on the intercession of the two official envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendants, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot-Inspecting Red Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Post Station Couriers, and the Memorial-Submitting Officers—each pair dispatched. I, your servant, humbly petition for the protection of my ailing body and the extension of my allotted years. This memorial, one copy, is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau. I await your decree with reverence.

chunks.original_text: 太上诸君丈人道炁，蒙恩所佑，每相欣慰，肉人无状，暴得疾病，合门大小，思过自责，归命大道，未蒙除差，所苦云云，日更困笃，惧恐奄忽，命在朝夕，气散神逝，往而不反，肉人惶怖，告臣求哀，谨为拜章，冒罪以闻，愿请地理宫中珠玉君一人，官将百二十人，朱衣赤帻，仗节铁斧立至，为某致百二十生气，禁三魂七魄不令去离某身，转益年寿，度名玉历，令得免臧除之例，永为种民，恩惟 太上分别，哀臣愚劣，谨因三官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神决吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞扶危，拯难续命，延年恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 疾病却三官死解章 具法位臣姓某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜 上言，某奉道失和，违负元始，身被三官重考，以某月日得病苦，某处痛不下饮食，列辞诉臣求乞平省，臣辄具以师法，谴问某身何所犯坐，某比首写归诚，乞丐生命，某疾从来，积日转更困笃，大小狼狈，肝胆涂地，臣不胜肉人性命，危急谨复，触冒拜章以闻，恩惟 太上，原赦肉人万死之厄，若某脏满罪定，名入死次，三命已尽，愿延一时，责以后善，使某追悔往罪，以修将来，谨为某上请天一君、真一君、好生君、延命君、拔命君五人，官将各百二十人，责臣章上诣 太浩天曹，北辰司命，韩君门下玉案上，却臣三官死解，定着生籍，重请无上天生君兵十万人，主收百二十杀鬼，却死来生，又请越干玉女二百人，为某增益仓谷，更延年寿，愿上章之日，时蒙放赦，应令某得出长夜，复见日月君将吏兵，言功举迁，以为效信，恩惟 太上分别，一晨臣愚劣，谨因二官直使正一功曹左右官使者，阴阳神次吏，科车赤符吏，刚风骑置驿马上章吏官，各二人出操，臣某谨为某求乞延年益筹，保病扶衰恩章一通，上诣 某天曹，伏须告报，臣某诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 太上宣总助化章卷之二竟 洞玄部表奏类

The Most High Lords and Venerable Dao Qi, by whose grace I am sheltered, have ever brought me joy. Yet this mortal, unworthy and ill-formed, has suddenly fallen gravely ill. My entire household, young and old, reflects upon its transgressions and humbly submits to the Great Dao. Though we have not yet been granted relief, my suffering persists, growing more severe with each passing day. I fear that in an instant, my life may hang by a thread—my qi scattered, my spirit departed, never to return. Terrified, I implore your servant to plead on my behalf. With this memorial, I dare to submit my petition, beseeching that one Pearl-and-Jade Lord from the Earthly Principles Palace, accompanied by one hundred and twenty officials and generals—clad in crimson robes and red headbands, bearing staffs and iron axes—be dispatched at once. May they bestow upon me the one hundred and twenty breaths of life, restrain my three *hun* and seven *po* souls from leaving my body, and prolong my years. Let my name be inscribed in the Jade Register, sparing me from the roster of those to be eradicated, that I may forever remain among the seed-people. I implore the Most High to discern my plea and take pity on my foolishness and inadequacy.

Relying on the intercession of the two official envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendants, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot-Inspecting Red Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Post Station Couriers, and the Memorial-Submitting Officers—each pair dispatched—I, your servant, humbly petition for deliverance from peril, rescue from calamity, and the extension of my life. This memorial, one copy, is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau. I await your decree with reverence.

A Petition to Dissolve the Three Offices’ Death Sentence
Your subordinate of such-and-such rank and name, with utmost trepidation, prostrates and kowtows, bowing twice to submit this plea.

I humbly state: I, having strayed from the Dao and lost harmony, have violated the will of the Primordial Beginning. My body is now subjected to the severe judgment of the Three Offices. On such-and-such a day of such-and-such a month, I fell gravely ill, suffering pain in such-and-such a place, unable to eat or drink. I have set forth my grievances and implored your servant to intercede, beseeching relief. In accordance with the teachings of my masters, I have inquired into the transgressions for which I am punished. I have confessed my faults in writing and begged for my life. My illness, persisting for days, grows ever more dire. My household, young and old, is in disarray, my liver and gall laid bare upon the earth. Unable to bear the peril to this mortal’s life, I dare once more to submit this memorial, touching my head to the ground in supplication.

I implore the Most High to pardon this mortal’s myriad deaths and dire straits. If my organs are full of sin and my fate sealed, my name entered among the dead, and my three lives exhausted, grant me but a moment’s reprieve. Hold me accountable for future good deeds, that I may repent my past transgressions and cultivate virtue henceforth. I humbly petition for the presence of the Heavenly One Lord, the True One Lord, the Life-Nurturing Lord, the Life-Extending Lord, and the Life-Rescuing Lord—five in all—each accompanied by one hundred and twenty officials and generals. May this memorial be presented to the Celestial Bureau of the Vast Heavenly Expanse, to the Northern Star Office of Life, and to the Jade Desk of Lord Han’s Gate, that my death sentence from the Three Offices be dissolved and my name firmly inscribed in the register of the living.

I further petition for the dispatch of one hundred thousand soldiers under the command of the Supreme Heavenly Lord of Life, tasked with capturing the one hundred and twenty death-dealing ghosts, turning death into life. I also beseech two hundred Jade Maidens of Yuegan to replenish my granaries and further extend my years. May this memorial, upon submission, swiftly secure your pardon, allowing me to emerge from eternal night and once more behold the sun and moon. May the generals, officials, and soldiers report my merits and recommend my advancement as a token of my sincerity.

I implore the Most High to discern my plea. In my foolishness and inadequacy, I rely on the intercession of the two official envoys, the Orthodox Unity Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendants, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Deciding Clerks, the Chariot-Inspecting Red Talisman Clerks, the Gale-Riding Post Station Couriers, and the Memorial-Submitting Officers—each pair dispatched. I, your servant, humbly petition for the extension of my years, the augmentation of my allotted span, the protection of my ailing body, and the support of my declining strength. This memorial, one copy, is respectfully submitted to the Celestial Bureau. I await your decree with reverence.

*Scroll Two of the Most High’s Proclamation of Universal Assistance and Transformation, concluded.*

chunks.original_text: 太上宣慈助化章 经名：太上宣总助化章。 唐末道士杜光庭编集。 五卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞玄部表奏类。 太上宣慈助化章卷三 广成先生杜光庭集 收犬子鬼章 具法位某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜上言，谨条，某州某县，某乡某里，某官某，为疾厄所侵，凶鬼为祟，上请天官君将吏兵，收捕石下犬子鬼，天官名号，件列如左。 上请玄老大将军兵士十万人，上请威明大将军兵士十万人，上请地里大将军兵士十万人，上请石仙大将军兵士十万人，上请五色大将军兵士十万人，上请节盖大将军兵士十万人，上请青盖大将军兵士十万人，上请赤盖大将军兵士十万人，上请白盖大将军兵士十万人，上请黑盖大将军兵士十万人，上请黄盖大将军兵士十万人，上请督天大将军兵士十万人。 右件一十二部天官君将吏兵一合降下，天充地坠，尽来径到某家身中，收捕某家所养石下大子之鬼，水官乳母杂神便斩杀之，以明大道之威，急急如律令。 勑某年太岁某某月某日某辰，祭酒臣谨移告抱壁州丘石郡太守，孔里县令封亭乡石叶里案前，件官所领境界山石下犬子鬼不争，小鬼侵入异土，病害某家某身，昼夜啼叫，疮痛痢疟，瘦疗不绝，寻看疾状，正是犬子小鬼，水官乳母等为害，各有州郡，由其所管太守检录不勤，致令放逸，伤害天人，从今已去，宜精加检录，不得有违，若或更来犯害某身者，收得斩之不恕，所主太守别加考责，一如太上老君律令。 泰玄都云云 上言，谨案某州某县某乡某里。

*Scroll Three of the Most High’s Proclamation of Compassionate Assistance and Transformation*
*Collected by:* Master of Broad Accomplishment, Du Guangting

**Memorial for the Seizure of the Stone-Dwelling Dog-Child Ghost**

Your servant, [Rank and Name], with reverence and awe, prostrates and bows twice, respectfully submitting this memorial:

I, [Name], of [State], [County], [Township], [Village], [Office and Name], now afflicted by illness and misfortune, am besieged by malevolent ghosts. I humbly petition the Celestial Officials, Generals, Officers, and Soldiers to seize and capture the Stone-Dwelling Dog-Child Ghost. The names and titles of the Celestial Officials are listed as follows:

I petition the Great General of the Mysterious Elder, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of Majestic Radiance, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of Earthly Terrain, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of Stone Immortals, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the Five Colors, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the Nodal Canopy, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the Azure Canopy, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the Vermilion Canopy, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the White Canopy, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the Black Canopy, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of the Yellow Canopy, with one hundred thousand soldiers.
I petition the Great General of Celestial Supervision, with one hundred thousand soldiers.

The aforementioned twelve divisions of Celestial Officials, Generals, Officers, and Soldiers shall descend in unison, filling the heavens and shaking the earth, arriving directly at my household and entering my body to seize and capture the Stone-Dwelling Dog-Child Ghost harbored within. The Water Officials, Wet-Nurses, and miscellaneous spirits shall execute them forthwith, manifesting the majesty of the Great Dao. *Hasten, hasten, in accordance with the statutes and ordinances!*

By decree of the [Year], the [Month], the [Day], and the [Hour], I, the Libationer and your servant, respectfully dispatch this memorial to the Prefect of Qiushi Commandery in Baobi Prefecture, the Magistrate of Kongli County, and the officials of Fengting Township and Shiye Village. The Stone-Dwelling Dog-Child Ghost within the jurisdiction of the aforementioned officials has transgressed without restraint. This petty ghost has trespassed into foreign territory, afflicting my household and my person with illness—wailing day and night, festering sores, dysentery, malaria, and unceasing emaciation. Upon examination, the symptoms confirm the harm wrought by the Dog-Child Ghost, the Water Officials, and the Wet-Nurses. Each resides within its respective commandery, yet the prefects responsible have failed in their diligence, allowing these spirits to roam freely and injure the people of heaven. Henceforth, they must exercise meticulous oversight and permit no further violations. Should these spirits dare to return and harm my person again, they shall be seized and executed without mercy. The disciple of the Great Dao, [Name], having long been entrusted to the Most High Lords of the Great Dao and the Venerable Masters, has relied upon the incense and offerings of the Three Masters for self-preservation and governance. Yet my cultivation and service have often faltered, and my movements and stillness have brought no benefit. Since the [day] of the [month], my son/daughter [Name] has fallen ill: limbs heavy, sores swollen, wailing day and night in pain, unable to nurse, unresponsive to medicine. Tracing the cause of this affliction, I fear it is the Dog-Child beneath the stones, the Water Officials, the Wet-Nurses who wash before the grove, the New Brides, and other ghosts lurking in our chambers, seizing our children, harming and killing them. I humbly submit this memorial, beseeching their eradication to save my child’s life, that they may thrive, grow to maturity, and continue our lineage. The depth of my distress moves me to pity. Unable to bear this suffering, I risk transgression and submit this memorial to the Heavenly Courts.

I implore the Most High Lord Lao, the Venerable Masters, the Celestial Masters, the Female Masters, and the Lords of the Five Qi under the Three Masters to extend your divine protection over me. Today, I invoke:
- The Azure Tiger of Mount Tai to devour the dog’s head and liver,
- The Vermilion Tiger of Mount Heng to devour the dog’s heart,
- The White Tiger of Mount Hua to devour the dog’s lungs,
- The Black Tiger of Mount Zhen to devour the dog’s kidneys,
- The Yellow Tiger of Mount Song to devour the dog’s spleen.

May the Tiger Armies of the Five Directions descend as one to consume the Dog-Child beneath the stones, the minor ghosts, the Water Officials, the Wet-Nurses, and the Five Pestilential Qi. May they hunt down and slay all those bound by curses, newly dead or long departed, malevolent spirits and specters—those who falsely style themselves:

- Magistrates of Kongli County,
- Lords of Fengting Township and Shiye Village,
- Cliff Kings, Generals of Forced Slaughter, Generals of Benevolent Connection to Heaven,
- The Azure Dog General of the East, the Vermilion Dog General of the South, the White Dog General of the West, the Black Dog General of the North, the Yellow Dog General of the Center,
- The Heavenly Gatekeeping Dog-Children, the Earthly Door-Guarding Dog-Children,
- The wolves with yellow heads, black mouths, azure ears, white paws, and white feet—some fifteen feet tall, others twelve—
- The Heavenly Prison Wet-Nurses, the Courtyard-Washing New Brides, who roam above and below, harming the young.

None shall escape the true qi of the Most High. I now dispatch talismans to the Governor of Wall Commandery and the Prefect of Stone Mound Prefecture, commanding them to exercise meticulous oversight and prevent further violations. I beseech the twelve divisions of celestial officials, generals, and soldiers to enter my body, encircle me front and back, and vigilantly guard against these spirits. Capture the Dog-Children, minor ghosts, the Five Pestilential Qi, the cold-malaria demons, the spirits of violent death, the newly dead and long departed, the archers and hunters, the ghosts of those shot or trapped. Cast nets and snares, eradicate them in sequence, and banish all my afflictions. May the might of the True and Orthodox Dao be manifest. May my child’s life be preserved, their suffering ended, their nursing restored, and their parents blessed. I humbly beseech the Boundless Great Dao, the Most High Masters, and the celestial officials to review this memorial and swiftly transmit it upward. Bestow upon me the qi of the Dao, that it may shield my body. I have investigated these malevolent spirits: they share no bond with my family, nor do they have descendants of their own. Though we have offered timely sacrifices, they have no right to afflict us. According to the statutes of the Orthodox Unity and the *Green Ghosts of the Civil Code*, they are subject to execution to pacify the people. I now petition:
- The Lord of Calamity’s Punishment, with 120 officials and generals, to govern the Granary of Brightness,

- The Luminous Harm-Averting Qi Officers,
- The Heavenly August Valiant Soldiers, 300,000 strong, to descend as one.

May they purge the malevolent spirits of violent death, the heterodox ghosts of unvenerated lineages, and all who falsely claim kinship. Seize, execute, annihilate, and sever them, leaving no trace. I further petition:
- Fifty soldiers each for the spirits of male and female misfortune, those who died of illness, drowning, imprisonment, burning, or by blade, beast, or wolf, to eradicate all foreign spirits and unvenerated gods who dare to afflict the innocent.

These spirits have no connection to our sacrifices, no shared altars, no kinship. They must be severed utterly. Should they dare to return, may rivers flow backward, white stones float, a thousand dogs tangle in silk, horses grow six-foot horns, fifty three-legged crows and three hundred nine-tailed foxes appear—only then may they seek me. Otherwise, let them be sundered from me by heaven and earth for ten thousand years, never to harass me again.

I also petition the Judgment Gods of the Five Directions—East, South, West, North, and Center—each with twelve officials and generals, to sever all recurring afflictions: year after year, month after month, day after day, hour after hour. May my illness vanish, my suffering cease, my life be secure, my soul purified, and all malevolent spirits subdued. May the true qi flow freely, and all pain and torment be dispelled. May I receive this grace.

To sever all unvenerated spirits and prevent further memorials, I, the humble official [Name], prostrate myself in awe and reverence, kowtowing twice to submit this memorial. I have reviewed the documents for [State], [County], [Township], [Village]. Your disciple [Name], fortunate to have long served the Great Dao under its protection, has known joy in its shelter. Yet my cultivation has faltered, inviting censure. Recently, I have suffered the depredations of malevolent ghosts, my life imperiled. I have received their pleas for memorials to distinguish their cases. Unable to bear this, I risk transgression and submit this memorial to the Heavenly Courts.

I pray the Most High Lord Lao, the Venerable Masters, the Celestial and Female Masters, and the Lords of the Five Qi under the Three Masters will review this humble servant’s memorial and transmit it swiftly. Bestow upon me the qi of the Dao to shield my body. I have investigated these malevolent spirits: they share no bond with my family, nor do they have descendants. I further petition fifty soldiers each for the spirits of male and female misfortune, those who died of illness, drowning, imprisonment, burning, or by blade, beast, or wolf, to eradicate all foreign spirits and unvenerated gods who dare to afflict the innocent. These spirits have no connection to our sacrifices, no shared altars, no kinship. They must be severed utterly. Should they dare to return, may rivers flow backward, white stones float, a thousand dogs tangle in silk, horses grow six-foot horns, fifty three-legged crows and three hundred nine-tailed foxes appear—only then may they seek me. Otherwise, let them be sundered from me by heaven and earth for ten thousand years, never to harass me again.

---

**Memorial for Dissolving Oaths and Curses of the Living and Dead**

[Rank and Name], in utmost reverence and awe, kowtows and bows twice to address this petition. As recorded in the documents: In [State], [County], [Township], [Village], the disciple [Name], aged [X] years, born on the [X] day of the [X] month, today presents this prayer. By fortunate fate, I was born into the Daoist gate and have revered the Great Dao, my name inscribed in the Mystic Register. Yet, despite years of devotion, my practice has been flawed, and misfortune has repeatedly befallen me. In the [X] year and [X] month, I suddenly fell ill, and the affliction has yet to abate. Day and night, I am consumed by dread, my life hanging by a thread. Upon examination, I fear I may have violated sacred oaths, suffered from hidden curses, or been harmed by malevolent forces. The suffering lingers, and my distress is boundless. I beseech this memorial to dissolve these bonds.

Your servant, unworthy as I am, dares to submit this petition to the Celestial Bureau, imploring the Most High Lord Lao, the Most High Elder, the Celestial Master, the Female Master, and the Three Masters, along with the Lords of the Five Qi, to deign to review this humble memorial and transmit it in due course. May the true qi of the Great Dao envelop me. I petition the celestial officials and soldiers to dissolve all curses and oaths from my ancestors—nine generations and seven lineages, thirty-six forebears—that may now afflict me. Whether they invoked spirits, called upon heaven and earth, pointed to the sun, moon, and stars, or swore by local shrines, talismanic temples, or any form—animate or inanimate, sentient or insentient—trees, stones, grasses, mountains, rivers, fire, or creatures; whether they slaughtered animals, drank blood, or ate flesh; whether they carved stones or broke metal as testimony—all such oaths, made by my forebears, now bring calamity upon their descendants. My illness persists, and my life is imperiled. Should I perish and descend to the Nine Springs, even the lowly sparrow and rat would cling to life. I beg for mercy and deliverance.

I humbly petition the Great Bing Lord of the Red Xun Palace, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to dissolve the curses and oaths of the living and dead from past and present. I further petition the Breaker of Malevolence Lord, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to seize and sever the spirits of curses and oaths. I petition the Great Protector General, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to safeguard the afflicted. May my illness be cured, my calamities dispelled, my years extended, and my countenance restored. May all curses cease.

For oaths sworn on the days of Zi, Chou, Yin, or Mao, may the divine lords of Zi, Chou, Yin, and Mao dissolve them. For oaths sworn on the days of Chen, Si, Wu, or Wei, may the divine lords of Chen, Si, Wu, and Wei dissolve them. For oaths sworn on the days of Shen, You, Xu, or Hai, may the divine lords of Shen, You, Xu, and Hai dissolve them. For oaths sworn by living creatures, may they be dissolved according to their kind. For oaths sworn by broken metal, stone, earth, or wood, may they dissolve of their own accord. May ten thousand oaths be eradicated, and a thousand calamities cease. On the day my wish is fulfilled, I shall receive profound grace.

By the merciful consideration of the Most High, this is thus invoked. Your servant humbly petitions, on behalf of [Name], for the celestial officials and soldiers to dissolve all oaths and curses from past and present, and to protect and heal the afflicted. A memorial, the *Chapter for Dissolving Oaths*, is presented to the [Name] Bureau, awaiting its proclamation.

With reverence and awe, I kowtow twice to submit this memorial.

---

**Memorial for Extending Life and Dispelling Calamities**

[Rank and Name], in utmost reverence and awe, kowtows and bows twice to address this petition. As recorded in the documents: In [State], [County], [Township], [Village], the disciple of the Great Dao, [Official Title and Name], aged [X] years, born on the [X] day of the [X] month, with a household of [X] persons, today prostrates and presents this prayer. I beseech the Great Dao of the Most High to accept this memorial, to support the weak, dispel calamities, extend my life, secure my fate, bring peace to my home, pacify the dragon spirits, protect my family, safeguard my wealth and fortune, resolve disasters, and preserve my life. My plea is earnest, and the reason is just.

Your servant, unworthy as I am, dares to submit this petition to the Celestial Bureau, imploring the Most High Lord Lao, the Most High Elder, the Celestial Master, the Female Master, and the Three Masters, along with the celestial officials and lords, to deign to review this humble memorial and transmit it in due course. May the true qi of the Great Dao envelop my household, ensuring the safety of all its members, dispelling calamities, dissolving misfortune, and ending all suffering.

I humbly petition the Life-Extending Lord of the Eastern Palace, with one hundred twenty officials, generals, and soldiers, to dispel the Three Disasters and Nine Calamities. I petition the Life-Extending Lord of the Southern Palace, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to dispel plagues, fires, and disasters. I petition the Life-Extending Lord of the Western Palace, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to dispel wars, injuries, and violent deaths. I petition the Life-Extending Lord of the Northern Palace, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to dispel illnesses, floods, and disasters. I petition the Life-Extending Lord of the Central Palace, with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to dispel calamities of the Five Lands, mountains, and rivers. I further petition the Seizer of Malevolence Lord, the Severer of Malevolence Lord, and the Breaker of Malevolence Lord, each with one hundred twenty officials and generals. I petition the Cloud-Dwelling Qiongqi, Devourer of Ghosts, with four hundred thousand soldiers of the Three-Legged Crows, and four hundred thousand soldiers of the Nine-Tailed Foxes. Together, may they descend as one, unite in purpose, ascend through the Gate of Heaven to the Nine Heavens, descend through the Gate of Earth to the Nine Hells, and traverse the Five Peaks, Four Rivers, Three Rivers, Four Seas, Nine Jiang, Eight Extremes, the Water Palace of the River Earl, Mount Tai, Fengdu, all great earthly prisons, the Three Terraces, Four Offices, and all celestial and terrestrial bureaus. May they dissolve all sins, calamities, punishments, and disasters—past and present, a thousand and ten thousand—of my family, kin, and dependents, young and old, male and female. May all disputes be resolved, and all punishments erased.

First, dissolve the calamities of the Celestial Net and Earthly Web. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Three Heavens, Eight Assemblies, and the Twenty-Eight Constellations. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Twelve Earthly Branches, Heavenly Stems, yearly punishments, monthly killings, and the inauspicious alignments of stars. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Three, Five, Seven, and Nine—nine unexpected disasters. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Two, Four, Six, and Eight—Five Phases, Eight Festivals, and the Eight Stars aligning with the year. Next, dissolve the calamities of household depletion, Five Inauspiciousnesses, Six Blows, female ghosts and oppressive spirits, harm to husbands, wives, sons, daughters, fathers, and mothers. Next, dissolve the calamities of moving, marriage, funerals, tomb entries, turning from yellow to black, from fortune to misfortune, from compliance to defiance, from words to ill omens, from kingship to decline. Next, dissolve the calamities of violating celestial and terrestrial taboos, forbidden years, months, days, hours, and lifespans. Next, dissolve the calamities of offending the Grand Year General, the Great Yin, Great Yang, Great and Lesser Depletions, the Twelve Monthly Establishments, the Seventy-Two Spirits, and the deities of Yin-Yang punishments and virtues. Next, dissolve the calamities of the newly and long-dead from the four directions and eight quarters, male and female death omens, broken arrows, funeral carriages, killing ghosts, star writings, and all forms of unjust and unnatural deaths. Next, dissolve the calamities of defying heaven and earth, breaking precepts, violating scriptures, betraying oaths, forgetting gratitude, lacking righteousness, and indulging in debauchery. Next, dissolve the calamities of others’ earth altars, talismanic temples, malevolent ghosts, and wandering calamities. Next, dissolve the calamities of new and old homes, blocked front and back, offending the Earth Lord, and suffering harm. Next, dissolve the calamities of livestock pens, mills, wells, latrines, and all forms of suppression and harm. Next, dissolve the calamities of past and present lives—nine generations and seven ancestors—lingering punishments, debts, and disputes passed to descendants. Next, dissolve the calamities of past and present grievous sins, unforgivable and irredeemable offenses. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Five Phases’ great prisons, the Nine Dark Hells, the Twenty-Four Prisons of Mount Tai, the Thirty-Six Bureaus of Fengdu, and the pursuit and capture of souls. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Celestial Bureau, Earthly Prison, the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water, and the black books of death records. Next, dissolve the calamities of others’ households—past and present—curses, oaths, and false connections. Next, dissolve the calamities of ancestors, parents, uncles, brothers, sisters, sons, nephews, and grandchildren—deaths and false connections. Next, dissolve the calamities of neighbors’ illnesses, plagues, and toxic qi. Next, dissolve the calamities of expeditions, punishments, robberies, murders, lawsuits, blades, official disasters, and unjust hardships. Next, dissolve the calamities of imprisonment, eastern penal servitude, and convict labor. Next, dissolve the calamities of tigers, wolves, snakes, and poisonous creatures. Next, dissolve the calamities of malicious plots, curses, and harmful oaths. Next, dissolve the calamities of livestock deaths, losses, and the depletion of wealth. Next, dissolve the calamities of wind, depletion, fatigue, cold, and the Four Hundred Four Diseases. Next, dissolve the calamities of the Five Directions and Five Disasters. Next, dissolve the calamities of exhausted fate, severed fortune, and ill omens. May all great and small calamities, great and small declines, of husbands, wives, sons, daughters, parents, and kin be dissolved.

May the Eastern Dipper inscribe my fate, the Western Dipper record my name, the Northern Dipper cast away death, and the Southern Dipper restore life. May my name be entered into the Jade Calendar and Green Register, granting me a lifespan of one hundred twenty years, forevermore.

chunks.original_text: 大道万岁种民，出入隆利，卜梦贞吉，公私和泰，年禄永延，所请天官君将吏兵有功勤者，随臣三会都章，言功举迁，不负信誓，恩惟 太上省理云云操，臣谨为某官某居家不利，分别灾厄，请天官吏兵，拜上解灾度厄大章一通，上诣 某曹，伏须告报，臣诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜以闻。 太上宣恳助化章卷之三竟 太上宣慈助化章卷四 广成先生杜光庭集 元皇上品六合生算章 具法位某，诚惶诚恐，稽首顿首，再拜上言谨条，弟子某口辞具列，比来为家轴轲，宅舍凶虚，梦想纷纭，诸无良利，即日叩头陈诸，乞弟子某生算度厄，增年益寿，解除妨害，推定生年生月，解灾度厄，防保身命章辞，但某自惟刍狗贱质，叨蒙至贵之身，朝菌之年，谬遇正真之道，祖宗倾仰，崇敬玄门，胤裔相承，归命 太上大道，隶属诸君丈人，荷沾慈卫，义重高天，奉赖熏修，恩深厚地，恐弟子某生逢五浊，运属三灾，识染六情，业逢九厄，心神迷闷，智慧昏昏，至於奉法，多违正教，致使真灵不佑，鬼炁相侵，比载已来，且多迍辕，所睹触犯非宜，无途可告，至於遇患，灾兴讼谪，宅舍不宁，人口瘦疗，然弟子某，入此岁初，肇临春夏，群乌乱呜，恶音不绝，梦想无善，衰难灾生，志向悉乖本意，或是弟子夫妻妨害，或是年命冲破，生月子午相冲，生日克身，有戾生年，计算不定，生月又有参差，受命生时，星历不稳，从兹一定，永劫毕身，轮寻用为，於后永定，若非会厄灾忌，即是宅舍受灾，或遇七伤之年，或当五鬼之岁，或遇四杀之月，或值六害之凶，或临八难之忧，或当七伤之忌，或临九坎之祸，或值十绝之殃，或恐弟子某前后移徙，不得吉日，出入失於良时，所向既犯恶神，晨昏复乖，天道触犯，无谢绿迍致凶，或夫妨妻子，刑及父母，命逢冲破，年到岁星，或入天门，或遇绝阳九厄之乡，或临地户绝阴入墓之凶，上为天罗所缠，下为地网所绕，魂囚魄击，幽闭三官，阴阳闭隔，且非灭没之忌，在此之年，穷绝之凶，正当今岁，前衰未定，后厄复兴，且会凶殃，屡逢轴轲，往往相克，频频涉害，弟子某即目情下不安，大小周悼，实为惊骇，自非上托玄极，生进扶救，无以爽此深灾，若不告投幽司上真除祸，何能遣斯灾厄，阖门惶怖，归心善护之门，拜首至真，归命香火之下，辞表乞恩，委命投臣，仰存恳切之甚，理实可哀，至诚至重，无容抑塞，小臣愚昧，尚乃未悟玄规，浅识之稽岂穷，幽旨人法易倒，鬼事难明，谨述短闻，究除情要，又恐某魂魄横被百鬼执迷，在於右宫黑簿之中，虚注上计名字，难可解释，谨为上请诸部天官君将吏兵部，具件如左： 上请赤天生算解厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请保命解对君一人，官将百二十人，上请保护度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请卫算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请益算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请延算度厄一人，官将百二十人，上请续算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请扶算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上清倍算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请定算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请生算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请保算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请招算度厄君一人，官将百二十人，上请拔算度厄君一人，官将百二十人。

chunks.original_text: 右状请劫诣前条诸曹府百鬼牢狱门下，请乞求觅弟子某三魂七魄，或横被百鬼执系前件曹府门下，请乞 太上大道省览章辞，上达应时，追拔放纵弟子某精光形影神炁，归付身中，悉令备具，延命生算，度脱衰厄，使生炁布流，百灵匡卫，如愿之日，奉荷 大道，罔极重恩，谨状。 即日通诣 三尊门下，申 天官门下，过 三师门下，奏 太上老君玉几前。 泰玄都正一平炁云云，但由弟子不闲科法，招延不利，比来住宅不安，人口疾厄，累岁述辅，梦想凶虚，鬼炁纷纭，人神无定，频延灾衰，即日诣臣，求乞章表，和解夫妻年命，推定星律，解释灾厄，防保身命，但臣受法之日，告盟三官，要当扶助师老，以救度为先，诸有凭祈，无容抑绝，谨按弟子某增添寿命，追解上计名字，拔赎魂魄，分解厄忌，防保身命，往以奉为。 太上诸君丈人道法，籍系玄都，仰崇三天，正法道炁，香章为命，得在道门，诚相劝化，自居此宅，凡百赠蹬，解途不善，伏闻 灵宝师老，有修斋谢过之科，正一盟威有立功补过之格，是以归心至极，翘仰玄门，恳注丹诚，拜上章辞，除灾解难，又恐弟子某足履地网，头戴天罗，连星等尽，灾杀加临，深恐一旦不免灾厄之次，次入图云云恩惟 太上老君，云云乞丐元炁，下流覆育弟子身命，谨请前条六十二部天官君将吏兵，次第拔赎弟子魂魄，往诣百鬼天牢地狱之内，求觅弟子某魂魄，付与身中，调和百节，安帖精神，追计解厄，定上生名，付与左契玉历之中，永保元吉，弟子灾厄并会，所奏章辞，恐不蒙上达，今奉帛素一疋，命米一斗二升，命丝百二十尺，银环一双，立信道门，以表丹诚之信，若树木枯朽，蓊养枝叶，仓谷乏少，益其斛斗，年命短促，延其丈尺，得在上古种民之次，又请元精父母十万人，一合下，赍持臣章，径诣太极玉皇几前，又请东王父西王母各一人，官将百二十人，一合下，主为弟子拔赎魂魄，增年益寿，禳灾却祸，收断家亲丈人，前亡后死注祟复连之炁，悉使断绝，拜章之后，住宅清宜，人口庆泰，百病不侵，灾衰度脱，如愿之日，被受重恩。 太上宣总助化章卷之四竟 太上宣慈助化章卷之五

Here follows the petition, beseeching that the preceding departments—all the bureaus, prisons, and gates of the hundred ghosts—be entreated to seek and retrieve the three hun and seven po of your disciple [Name]. Should they have been wrongfully seized and bound by the hundred ghosts in any of the aforementioned bureaus or gates, may the Most High and Great Dao deign to peruse this memorial, that it be swiftly conveyed on high. May the luminous essence, form, shadow, and spirit-qi of your disciple [Name] be pursued, released, and restored to his body, fully reconstituted, that his life’s allotment be extended, his misfortunes dissolved, and his vital qi spread and flow. May the hundred spirits come to his aid and defense. On the day his prayers are answered, he shall bear in reverence the boundless grace of the Great Dao.

This day, the petition is duly presented at the Gate of the Three Honored Ones, submitted to the Gate of the Celestial Officials, passed through the Gate of the Three Masters, and laid before the jade table of the Most High Lord Lao.

At the Great Mystery Capital of the Orthodox Unity and Balanced Qi, it is said: Through this disciple’s unfamiliarity with the rites and precepts, he has invited misfortune. Of late, his dwelling has known no peace; his household has suffered illness and adversity. For years, he has sought aid in vain, his dreams filled with ominous emptiness, his home thick with ghostly qi, his spirits unsettled. Disasters and decline have followed one upon another. Today, he comes before me, beseeching memorials and petitions to harmonize the destinies of husband and wife, to determine the stellar influences, to dispel calamities, and to safeguard his life.

From the day I received the Daoist precepts, I pledged before the Three Officials to uphold and assist my masters and elders, making salvation my foremost duty. In all matters of supplication, I may not refuse or reject. Thus, I respectfully act on behalf of your disciple [Name] to augment his lifespan, to retrieve and absolve his name from the registers of the dead, to redeem his hun and po, to dissolve his misfortunes and taboos, and to protect his life, as herein petitioned.

The Daoist methods of the Most High Lords and Perfected Ones are recorded in the Mysterious Capital, revered under the Three Heavens. The true qi of the Dao and the law are sustained by incense and memorials. Within the gates of the Dao, we earnestly exhort and transform. Dwelling in this abode, beset by all manner of setbacks and misfortune, I have learned of the rites of the Numinous Treasure masters for repentance through purification, and of the Orthodox Unity Alliance’s威 for establishing merit to atone for transgressions. Thus, with utmost sincerity, I turn my heart toward the Mysterious Gate, offering my earnest devotion and presenting this memorial to dispel disaster and resolve hardship.

Yet I fear that your disciple [Name] treads the snares of the earthly net, his head caught in the heavenly toils, his stars exhausted, and baleful influences descending upon him. Deeply apprehensive that he may at any moment fall prey to calamity, he entreats the Most High Lord Lao to bestow the primordial qi, flowing downward to nurture and shield his life.

I respectfully invoke the sixty-two divisions of celestial officials, generals, clerks, and soldiers listed above to proceed in order to redeem your disciple’s hun and po. Let them journey to the celestial prisons and earthly hells of the hundred ghosts, seek out your disciple [Name]’s hun and po, and restore them to his body, harmonizing his limbs and settling his spirit. Let his name be removed from the registers of the dead and his lifespan secured, inscribed in the jade calendar of the left contract, that he may forever enjoy primordial auspiciousness.

Should the misfortunes of your disciple converge, and this memorial fail to reach the heavens, I now offer one bolt of plain silk, one *dou* and two *sheng* of rice, one hundred twenty *chi* of silk thread, and a pair of silver rings as tokens of faith in the Daoist gate, to manifest the sincerity of my devotion. Just as withered trees may flourish with nurtured branches and leaves, or depleted granaries be replenished with measures of grain, may a shortened lifespan be extended in length, that he may join the ranks of the ancient seed-people.

I further invoke the Primordial Essence Father and Mother and one hundred thousand attendants to descend together, bearing this memorial directly to the jade table of the Supreme Jade Emperor. I also invoke the Eastern King Father and Western Queen Mother, each with one hundred twenty officials and generals, to descend together and redeem your disciple’s hun and po, augment his years and extend his life, avert disasters and repel misfortune. May the lingering qi of departed kin—those who have passed before and after, and any malevolent influences—be severed and dissolved.

After this memorial is presented, may his dwelling be purified and harmonious, his household joyous and secure, free from illness and misfortune. When his prayers are answered, he shall receive the profound grace of the Most High.

*This concludes the fourth scroll of the* Most High’s Proclamation of Universal Assistance in Transformation.
*This is the fifth scroll of the* Most High’s Proclamation of Compassionate Assistance in Transformation.

chunks.translated_text:
The Dao’s boundless, immeasurable grace—this petition is humbly submitted.

On the first day of the [day] month in the year [year], in [village], [precinct], [county], [prefecture], your disciple [name], aged [age], of a household of [number] persons, now residing at [location], prostrates himself this day to beseech your favor. He petitions your servant, presenting this memorial to the Three Heavens, imploring their mandate to bolster his declining years, deliver him from peril, extend his life’s tally, and augment his longevity.

Alas, your disciple’s entire household, benighted and foolish, has been granted the privilege of entering the gates of the Dao and born into this mortal generation, yet remains mired in the realm of ordinary beings. Since the onset of this year’s early spring, he has encountered successive misfortunes—calamity, peril, and danger—with no auspicious dreams to console him. He fears that adversity, disaster, and decline will converge upon him, that his years will be exhausted and his tally spent, that myriad afflictions will descend, and that his three hun and seven po will be imprisoned in the celestial dungeons and earthly hells, his name recorded in the Register of Deaths of the Three Offices—Heaven, Earth, and Water—within the grasp of the Five Punishments and Six Harms. His household is gripped by dread, and peace and stability elude them.

With a single heart, he places his trust in the great Dao and entrusts his fate to the Perfected Ones, beseeching your servant to submit this memorial, that his life may be prolonged, his perils delivered, his years extended, and his longevity increased. He begs for the bestowal of true qi to nurture and shield his mortal form, that the generals, officers, soldiers, and swift courier-horses of his life and destiny may soar forth to the gates of the Three Offices—Heaven, Earth, and Water—to intercede on behalf of your disciple. May his name be expunged from the Register of Deaths, his three hun and seven po retrieved and restored to his body, that he may pass through the gates of disaster and peril and forever join the ranks of the ancient seed-people.

When his prayers are answered, he shall reverently receive the profound grace.

This day, we proceed to the Supreme Mystery Capital in all haste. Yet due to this disciple’s ignorance of the statutes and rituals, his devotion to the Dao has been fraught with transgressions, inviting misfortune. Recently, his household has suffered adversity: the dwelling is plagued by inauspicious emptiness, dreams are chaotic and tangled, ghostly *qi* congeals and lingers, family members suffer from swellings and pains, and divination reveals manifold taboos. This disciple [Name] humbly declares: since the onset of this year, his life and fate have been beset by calamities, a multitude of hardships, and the exhaustion of his allotted lifespan. The stars of doom press upon him in unbroken succession; his misfortune is recorded in the ledgers of the Three Officials’ *Death and Release* accounts, bound within the Five Punishments and Six Harms. Above, he is ensnared by the Heavenly Net; below, he is entangled by the Earthly Web. Fearing that he may not escape these disasters, misfortunes, and perils in an instant, his entire household is gripped by private anguish, nightly dread, and knows not what recourse to take. Thus, with wholehearted devotion, he places his trust in the Great Dao, entrusting his fate to the Most Perfect and True, and beseeches this minister to submit a memorial, that this disciple [Name] may be upheld in his decline, delivered from calamity, his lifespan extended, his years increased, his *hun* and *po* retrieved and restored to his body, all made complete.

May all malevolent *qi*—whether from internal or external sources, whether stubborn specters, perverse spirits, or lingering demonic infestations—be eradicated in due order, preserving his life and fate. Should he be marked for death, let it be proclaimed that the Calamity Lord alone, along with one hundred and twenty officials and generals, be dispatched to guard and protect this disciple [Name], securing his life, stabilizing his *hun* and *po*, expunging his name from the registers of death, and inscribing it in the rolls of the living. May his granaries overflow with grain, his lifespan be prolonged, his decline upheld, his calamities delivered, and the *qi* of life flow abundantly.

After this memorial is presented, may his dwelling become harmonious and pure, his household thrive in health, his misfortunes be dispelled, and celestial disasters forever averted. May his transgressions be absolved, his debts dissolved, and a hundred spirits come to his defense. The celestial officials, generals, officers, and soldiers who accompany this minister’s triennial memorial shall report his merits and promote his rank as a token of efficacy.

We implore the Most High, Boundless, and Great Dao; the Most Venerable Masters; and the celestial administrators to bestow their compassion and attend to this plea. Respectfully, on behalf of disciple [Name], we bow before the celestial officials, generals, officers, and soldiers, beseeching them to uphold his decline, deliver him from calamity, increase his years, prolong his lifespan, and petition the Three Heavens to retrieve his *hun* and *po*, restoring them to his body in full. May the Celestial Physicians heal his ailments, safeguard his life, and grant him peace free from harm.

Your servant humbly presents this petition for grace, submitting it to the celestial bureaus, and awaits their decree. With utmost reverence and trepidation, I kowtow, prostrate myself, and bow twice to make this known.

*Thus concludes the fifth scroll of the* Taishang Xuanzhu Huazhang.
